questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NRG-1

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are mesenchymal tumors that commonly present with gastrointestinal bleeding. They are characterized by mutations that lead to the overactivity of tyrosine kinase. The most common mutation associated with GISTs is in the CKIT gene, which leads to the activation of the KIT receptor tyrosine kinase.

 

NRG-1 (Neuregulin 1):

 

NRG-1 is a gene that is part of the epidermal growth factor receptor family. It is not associated with GISTs. Instead, NRG-1 is implicated in the pathogenesis of mental health disorders, such as schizophrenia. Therefore, it is not used as a marker for GISTs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. KIT: KIT mutations are the most common genetic alterations found in GISTs and are critical for the diagnosis and treatment of these tumors.

 

Option B. PDGFR: Mutations in the PDGFR gene occur in a subset of GISTs and play a role similar to KIT mutations in tumor development.

 

Option C. SDH: SDH mutations are linked to Carney-Stratakis syndrome and are significant markers in a subset of GISTs. These mutations lead to defects in cellular respiration and are associated with the development of GISTs and paragangliomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NRG-1 is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors. The primary markers for GISTs include KIT, PDGFR, and SDH mutations.

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone 

 

SALTER HARRIS CLASSIFICATION 

  • The arrangement of cells of the physis is in layers or zones. 
  • These layers include the reserve, proliferative and hypertrophic zones. 
  • The reserve zone serves as the storage area for lipids, proteoglycans, and glycogen for growth and matrix production later. 
  • The proliferative zone has the highest rate of extracellular matrix production and accounts for the most abundant longitudinal growth. 
  • The hypertrophic zone has three phases: 
    • Maturation allows for preparation for calcification
    • Degenerative further prepare the matrix
    • Provisional calcification zone is where chondrocyte death occurs, allowing for calcium release. 
  • Physeal fractures most commonly occur in the zone of provisional calcification, as it is the weakest in response to shearing stress. 
  • The physis is weaker than ligaments or periosteum in children, causing injury to the growth plate before other structures. 
  • Zones of physis:

 

 

 

  • Salter and Harris described two major types of epiphyseal plates: the pressure epiphysis and the traction epiphysis. 
  • Pressure epiphyses provide longitudinal growth, at the end of long bones, are intra-articular, and bear weight. 
  • Traction epiphyses provide appositional growth, at the origin or insertion of muscles, are extra-articular, and do not bear weight. 
  • Their classification focuses on injuries at pressure epiphyses. 
  • They recognized that physeal fractures consistently occur through the same histologic plane called the zone of provisional calcification. 
  • This zone, located in the zone of hypertrophy, represents a transitional point between calcified and non-calcified extracellular matrix proteins, making it weaker than its surrounding osseous-ligamentous structures, and therefore more susceptible to injury.

 

 

  • In type I injury, there is slip of epiphysis with damage to the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Resting zone: It is affected in storage disorders like Gaucher’s disease. 

 

Option B. Proliferative zone: It is affected in growth hormone defects like Larsen’s syndrome. 

 

Option D. Zone of provisional calcification: It is affected in mineralization defects like rickets. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. 
  • It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. 
  • Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely tumor arising from the slide shown in the image?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma

 

The provided histopathological image shows multiple gland formations, which is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinomas are malignant tumors that arise from glandular epithelial cells. The presence of glandular structures in the histological slide is a key indicator of this type of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of carcinoma is characterized by the presence of keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, which are not seen in the provided image.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of the lymphoid tissue and do not typically show glandular patterns in histology.

 

Option D. Sarcoma: Sarcomas arise from mesenchymal cells and are characterized by spindle-shaped cells. They do not exhibit glandular formations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is identified by the presence of glandular formations in histopathological slides.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are the complications associated with GERD? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Asthma
  2. Laryngitis
  3. Pulmonary Fibrosis
  4. Chronic cough
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a chronic condition where stomach contents flow back into the esophagus, causing various symptoms and complications. The complications of GERD can extend beyond the esophagus, affecting the respiratory system and other areas.

 

  1. Asthma: GERD can exacerbate asthma symptoms. The reflux of stomach acid can irritate the airways and lungs, triggering asthma attacks or making existing asthma more difficult to control.
  2. Laryngitis: Acid reflux can lead to inflammation of the larynx (voice box), causing laryngitis. Symptoms may include hoarseness, throat pain, and voice changes.
  3. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Although less common, chronic aspiration of gastric contents due to GERD can contribute to the development of pulmonary fibrosis. This is particularly seen in patients with diffuse scleroderma, where severe GERD is a significant risk factor for interstitial lung disease (ILD).
  4. Chronic cough: GERD is a recognized cause of chronic cough. The reflux of acid can irritate the esophagus and respiratory tract, leading to a persistent cough.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GERD can lead to a variety of extra-esophageal complications, including asthma, laryngitis, pulmonary fibrosis, and chronic cough. Recognizing these complications is crucial for the comprehensive management of patients with GERD.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction

 

Photophobia and watering in a 3-month-old child can be caused by various conditions. Here’s a closer look at each condition:

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: This condition typically presents with excessive tearing (lacrimation) due to blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. However, it does not cause photophobia. Photophobia indicates sensitivity to light, which is not a feature of nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • Congenital entropion: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This can lead to corneal abrasions, resulting in both photophobia and watering.
  • Congenital glaucoma: This is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to a triad of symptoms: photophobia, lacrimation, and blepharospasm (eyelid twitching). It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.
  • Congenital distichiasis: This condition involves an extra row of eyelashes, which can irritate the cornea, leading to corneal abrasions. This irritation can cause both photophobia and lacrimation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: As explained, this condition causes lacrimation but not photophobia. This makes it the to the question of which condition cannot cause photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is associated with excessive tearing but does not cause photophobia. Other conditions like congenital entropion, congenital glaucoma, and congenital distichiasis can cause both photophobia and watering due to corneal involvement and irritation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with regurgitation of food and weight loss over the past several months. A barium swallow is performed. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia cardia

 

The patient presents with symptoms of regurgitation and weight loss, and a barium swallow shows a characteristic "bird's beak" appearance. This finding is highly suggestive of achalasia cardia.

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a functional obstruction of the esophagus. The classic radiographic feature seen on a barium swallow is a smooth, tapered narrowing at the lower esophagus resembling a bird's beak. Symptoms include progressive dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and weight loss.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Esophageal carcinoma: While esophageal carcinoma can present with similar symptoms, it typically occurs in older patients (50yr+) and may produce a similar radiographic appearance, known as "pseudoachalasia." However, the age of the patient and the classic bird's beak appearance make achalasia the more likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Zenker's diverticulum: This condition involves the formation of a diverticulum in the hypopharynx, leading to symptoms such as dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis. The radiographic appearance is different, typically showing a pouch at the back of the throat, rather than the bird's beak seen in achalasia.

 

Option D. Diffuse esophageal spasm: This condition presents with intermittent dysphagia and chest pain. The barium swallow typically shows a corkscrew esophagus due to simultaneous, uncoordinated contractions, which is distinct from the bird's beak appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia cardia is characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, leading to a bird's beak appearance on a barium swallow. This is the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with regurgitation of food and weight loss.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after three days of abdominal pain and vomiting. His laboratory reports revealed a potassium value of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be seen except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebral edema

 

The patient has hypokalemia, indicated by a potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L.

 

This is not seen with Cerebral edema, which is typically associated with hyponatremia (low sodium levels) rather than hypokalemia. Hyponatremia can lead to an osmotic imbalance, causing water to move into brain cells and resulting in cerebral edema. This is not a recognized complication of hypokalemia.

 

Other options:

 

Hypokalemia can lead to several clinical manifestations:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia, due to its effect on cardiac electrical activity. Potassium is crucial for maintaining normal heart rhythm, and its deficiency can lead to dangerous arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Quadriparesis: Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness and paralysis, including quadriparesis. It affects muscle function because potassium is essential for normal muscle cell function and nerve transmission. Severe hypokalemia can mimic conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemia can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition occurs due to a defect in the kidney's ability to respond to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to excessive urination and thirst. Hypokalemia impairs the kidney's concentrating ability, contributing to this disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral edema is not associated with hypokalemia; it is a complication of hyponatremia. Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most seen with which STI? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhoea

 

Explanation:

 

  • Gonorrhoea, caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, is known for developing significant resistance to multiple antibiotics.
  • Over the years, Neisseria gonorrhoeae has shown resistance to several classes of antibiotics, including penicillin, tetracycline, and fluoroquinolones.
  • More recently, there has been an increasing number of reports of resistance to cephalosporins, including ceftriaxone, which is currently the first-line treatment for Gonorrhoea.
  • The development of drug resistance in Gonorrhoea is largely due to the bacterium's ability to acquire resistance genes through horizontal gene transfer and spontaneous mutations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, has not shown the same level of widespread antibiotic resistance as gonorrhoea. It is typically treated with antibiotics such as azithromycin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, or erythromycin.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, is relatively rare and has not shown significant issues with antibiotic resistance. It is usually treated with azithromycin, doxycycline, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically treated with penicillin. Although there have been some cases of resistance to macrolides like azithromycin, penicillin remains highly effective, and there is no widespread resistance to it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gonorrhoea is the STI most commonly associated with significant and increasing antibiotic resistance, posing a major challenge to treatment and control efforts worldwide.

questions.text:
Which of the following are properties of ventricular muscle fibers: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. All or none law
  2. Length-tension relation
  3. Tetanus
  4. Long refractory period
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, and 4

 

Explanation

 

Ventricular muscle fibers exhibit several unique properties that are crucial for their function:

 

1. All or None Law: This principle states that a single muscle fiber will either contract fully or not at all in response to a stimulus. Ventricular muscle fibers act as a syncytium due to the presence of gap junctions made up of connexin proteins, which allows them to follow the all-or-none law. Thus, this property is true for ventricular muscle fibers.

 

2. Length-Tension Relation: The length-tension relationship in ventricular muscle fibers is a reflection of the Frank-Starling law, which states that the force of contraction of the heart muscle is proportional to its initial length (or end-diastolic volume, EDV). This relationship is crucial for adjusting cardiac output based on the volume of blood returning to the heart. Within physiological limits, an increase in the initial length of the muscle fiber increases the force of contraction.

 

4. Long Refractory Period: Ventricular muscle fibers have a long refractory period due to the extended plateau phase in their action potential. This long refractory period is crucial in preventing tetanus and ensuring that the heart muscle relaxes fully before the next contraction, maintaining efficient pumping action.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Tetanus: Tetanus is a sustained muscle contraction that occurs when the muscle is stimulated at a high frequency. However, due to the long refractory period in ventricular muscle fibers, tetanus is not possible. The plateau phase (phase 2) of the cardiac action potential is prolonged, which ensures that the heart muscle cannot be re-stimulated before the previous contraction is complete. This prevents sustained contractions (tetanus), which would be detrimental to cardiac function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular muscle fibers follow the all-or-none law, have a length-tension relationship (Frank-Starling law), and possess a long refractory period that prevents tetanus.

questions.text: Identify the 2nd generation supraglottic airway device from the options given below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LMA Proseal

 

The LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device. Second-generation devices are designed to be safer than first-generation devices, offering a higher pressure pharyngeal seal and a reduced risk of aspiration. These devices often have two tubes: one for ventilation (airway tube) and another for draining gastric secretions (gastric tube). The LMA Proseal, specifically, features these characteristics, making it a second-generation device.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LMA Fastrach: LMA Fastrach, also known as the intubating LMA, is not categorized as either a first or second-generation device. It is classified as a special LMA due to its unique design, which facilitates difficult intubations.

 

 

Option B. LMA Flexible: The LMA Flexible is a variant of the LMA Classic, which is a first-generation device. It has a flexible airway tube but lacks the features of second-generation devices, such as a high-pressure pharyngeal seal and an additional tube for gastric drainage.

 

 

Option D. Ambu LMA: The Ambu LMA does not have the dual-tube system that characterizes second-generation devices.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

LMA Proseal is a second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by its two-tube system that enhances safety by reducing the risk of aspiration

choices.text: Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is un-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is non-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor
Drug A is un-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the drugs shown in graph A and graph B is correct. (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

 

To determine the correct answer, let's analyze the Lineweaver-Burk plots and the types of enzyme inhibition they represent:

 

For non-competitive inhibitors, the lines intersect at the x-axis. This type of inhibitor decreases VmaxVmax​ without affecting KmKm​.

 

Option A. Competitive Inhibition: On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibitors intersect with the no-inhibitor line at the y-axis. This is because competitive inhibitors increase the apparent KmKm​ (Michaelis constant) without affecting VmaxVmax​ (maximum velocity).

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors result in parallel lines on the Lineweaver-Burk plot. They decrease both VmaxVmax​ and KmKm​ proportionally. 

 

Given the descriptions of the graphs:

 

  • Graph A: The lines meet at the y-axis, indicating competitive inhibition.
  • Graph B: The lines start from the same point on the x-axis, indicating non-competitive inhibition.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

B. Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: Declaration of Oslo is for? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Therapeutic abortion

 

The Declaration of Oslo was adopted by the World Medical Association (WMA) to address the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion. Therapeutic abortion refers to the termination of pregnancy performed to save the life of the pregnant woman, preserve her physical or mental health, or in cases of severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torture: The Declaration of Tokyo is the relevant document that deals with the ethical guidelines for doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment.

 

Option C. Hunger: The Declaration of Malta on Hunger Strikes provides ethical guidelines for physicians concerning the treatment of hunger strikers. This declaration emphasizes the importance of respecting the autonomy of individuals who engage in hunger strikes.

 

Option D. Ethical aspects of medical research: The Declaration of Helsinki is the key document that outlines ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects. It emphasizes the necessity of informed consent, the welfare of research participants, and the importance of conducting research with scientific integrity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Declaration of Oslo specifically addresses the ethical considerations involved in therapeutic abortion, distinguishing it from other declarations that focus on different ethical issues in medical practice

questions.text: Which one is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purulent conjunctivitis

 

Purulent conjunctivitis is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease. Instead, the conjunctivitis seen in Kawasaki disease is non-purulent and sterile, meaning it does not produce pus, and cultures are negative.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute, self-limited vasculitis that predominantly affects children. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease include the presence of fever for at least five days, along with at least four of the following five clinical features:

 

  1. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (conjunctivitis): This is a common feature in Kawasaki disease, but it is non-purulent (does not produce pus).
  2. Changes in the lips and oral cavity: This includes strawberry tongue (a red, bumpy tongue), erythema, and cracking of the lips.
  3. Polymorphous rash: A rash of various forms can be present.
  4. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Typically unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm in diameter.
  5. Changes in the extremities: This includes erythema of the palms and soles, edema of the hands and feet, and later desquamation (peeling) of the skin.

 

TOC - IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) ± Aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rash: A polymorphous rash is one of the key diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is another diagnostic criterion, usually unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm.

 

Option D. Strawberry tongue: Changes in the lips and oral cavity, including strawberry tongue, are diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is diagnosed based on a set of clinical criteria, including non-purulent conjunctivitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, and changes in the oral cavity such as strawberry tongue. Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue degradation disorder is associated with aortic aneurysm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marfan's Syndrome

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that affects the body's connective tissues, which provide structural support to various organs and tissues. It is particularly associated with cardiovascular complications, including aortic aneurysms and dissections. This is due to the weakening of the aortic wall caused by defective fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the elasticity and strength of the connective tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: While Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) can lead to vascular complications, including aortic aneurysms, it is specifically the vascular type (Type IV) of EDS that is associated with these issues. However, Marfan's Syndrome is more commonly linked to aortic aneurysms.

 

Option C. Atherosclerosis: Atherosclerosis is a condition characterized by the build-up of plaque within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing and hardening of the arteries. It is a risk factor for abdominal aortic aneurysm but is not classified as a connective tissue disorder.

 

Option D. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, leading to defective collagen synthesis. While it results in symptoms like mucosal bleeding and poor wound healing, it is not associated with aortic aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder closely associated with the development of aortic aneurysms due to the defective fibrillin-1 protein affecting the structural integrity of the aortic wall.

questions.text: A decrease in GFR is associated with which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure

 

If the hydrostatic pressure of the capillaries or the oncotic pressure of the Bowman's capsule decreases, filtration will decrease. If the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillary increases or if the hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman's capsule increases, GFR will decrease as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is determined by the net filtration pressure, which depends on various pressures within the glomerulus and Bowman's capsule:

 

Option A. Increased Renal Blood Flow: This increases GFR as more blood flow leads to higher filtration.

 

Option B. Increased Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure: This also increases GFR because higher pressure in the glomerulus drives more filtrate into Bowman's capsule.

 

Option D. Decreased Glomerular Oncotic Pressure: This increases GFR because lower protein concentration in the glomerulus reduces the opposing force to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure reduces net filtration pressure (NFP) and decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Increased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases filtration pressure and GFR.

questions.text: Which joint is not formed by the bone shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The image shows a thoracic vertebra, identifiable by its long spinous process, body, and superior and inferior articular facets. Thoracic vertebrae participate in forming several types of joints but do not form synchondroses. A synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage, which is not present in the thoracic vertebra.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: Incorrect. Syndesmosis joints are formed where two bones are connected by a ligament. An example related to the vertebrae would be the interspinous ligament connecting adjacent spinous processes.

 

Option C. Plane joint: Incorrect. Plane joints are formed by thoracic vertebrae, such as the costovertebral and costotransverse joints, where the ribs articulate with the thoracic vertebrae.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Incorrect. Symphysis joints are formed between the vertebral bodies of adjacent thoracic vertebrae via the intervertebral discs, which are composed of fibrocartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracic vertebrae do not form synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous) joints; they are involved in forming plane joints, syndesmosis, and symphysis joints.

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which type of sensation is carried by the 2nd order neuron of the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pain

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain. The second-order neurons in this nucleus relay these sensations to higher brain centers for processing. This pathway is crucial for the perception of painful stimuli and temperature changes, ensuring appropriate responses to potential dangers or injuries.

 

Note -

 

  • The trigeminal nerve has two types of nuclei: a motor nucleus and sensory nuclei.
  • The motor nucleus is singular and located in the pons.
  • The sensory nuclei are more numerous, consisting of three different nuclei distributed within the brainstem:
    • Mesencephalic Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (MNT): This nucleus is situated in the midbrain and is part of the sensory nuclei.
    • Chief Sensory Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (CNT): Located in the pons, this nucleus primarily handles the main sensory functions of the trigeminal nerve.
    • Spinal Nucleus of the Trigeminal Nerve (also referred to as SNT): This extends down to the medulla and is involved with transmitting pain and temperature sensations from the face to the brain.
  • Four nuclei: (3 sensory +1 Motor).
  • General somatic afferent:
    1. Mesencephalic (midbrain & pons): receives proprioceptive fibers from face
    2. Principal (main) sensory (pons): receives touch fibers from face.
    3. Spinal (pons, medulla & upper 2-3 cervical segments of spinal cord): receives pain & temperature sensations from face.
  • Special visceral efferent:

4. Motor nucleus (pons): supplies:

  • Four muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, medial & lateral pterygoid).
  • Other four muscles (Anterior belly of diagstic, mylohyoid, tensor tympani & tensor palati).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proprioception: Proprioception is managed by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus. This nucleus is responsible for sensing the position and movement of the jaw muscles, contributing to reflexes such as the jaw jerk.

 

Option B. Touch: The chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve handles the sensation of touch. This nucleus receives tactile information from the face and transmits it to the brain.

 

Option D. Vibration: Vibration sense is also managed by the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. This nucleus is involved in processing detailed touch and vibratory sensations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve carries pain and temperature sensations, distinguishing it from the other nuclei responsible for proprioception, touch, and vibration.

choices.text: Loud S1 is a common finding
Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chest pain and upper respiratory tract infection, seven days ago, presents with shortness of breath. She has BP of 100/60 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110/min. Chest x-ray reviews an enlarged heart, which appears like a water bottle. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loud S1 is a common finding

 

The patient is likely suffering from pericardial effusion, possibly progressing to cardiac tamponade, secondary to a recent viral infection. This is suggested by the history of an upper respiratory tract infection, the physical findings, and the characteristic "water bottle" appearance of the heart on the chest x-ray.

 

The incorrect statement is Loud S1 is a common finding. In fact, one of the hallmarks of cardiac tamponade is muffled or distant heart sounds due to the insulating effect of the pericardial fluid, as described in Beck's triad, which includes hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus Paradoxus is usually seen: This is true. Pulsus paradoxus is a significant drop in blood pressure during inspiration, common in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Pericardiocentesis may be required: This is true. Pericardiocentesis is often necessary to remove the excess fluid and relieve pressure on the heart, especially if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 

Option D. Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse: This is true. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure from the pericardial fluid prevents the right atrium and right ventricle from expanding during diastole, leading to their collapse. Echocardiography will reveal this diastolic collapse, confirming cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds are a key finding, not a loud S1.

questions.text: FISH can detect all except which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point mutation

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a cytogenetic technique used to detect and localize specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It can detect chromosomal abnormalities such as amplifications, deletions, and translocations. However, FISH cannot detect point mutations because these are small-scale changes in DNA sequence that occur at the molecular level, not at the chromosomal level that FISH is designed to analyze.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Amplification: As FISH can detect gene amplifications, which are increases in the number of copies of a particular gene.

 

Option B. Deletion: Because FISH can identify chromosomal deletions, where a segment of a chromosome is missing.

 

Option C. Translocation: As FISH is commonly used to detect chromosomal translocations, where segments of chromosomes have exchanged places.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization) can detect chromosomal abnormalities like amplifications, deletions, and translocations, but cannot detect point mutations, which require molecular methods such as PCR for identification.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. She has irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopic beats. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium Carbonate

 

Barium carbonate poisoning is characterized by severe hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which leads to symptoms such as muscle paralysis and irregular pulse. The ECG changes, such as multiple ventricular ectopic beats, are also indicative of hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aluminum Phosphide: This poison releases phosphine gas in the stomach, which inhibits cytochrome C oxidase and causes oxidative stress, leading to cytotoxic effects. The main symptom is profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option B. Zinc Phosphide: Similar to aluminum phosphide, zinc phosphide also releases phosphine gas and causes oxidative stress and cytochrome C oxidase inhibition, leading to cytotoxic effects and profound hypotension, not hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Warfarin: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that causes bleeding and bruising with an elevated PT/INR, but it does not cause hypokalemia or the associated symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia with symptoms such as muscle paralysis, irregular pulse, and ECG changes like ventricular ectopic beats strongly suggest poisoning with barium carbonate.

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) OCD

 

The Mental Health Gap Action Program (mhGAP) by the World Health Organization (WHO) is designed to scale up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The program focuses on priority conditions that are of high burden and can be managed effectively in primary care settings.

 

The mnemonic "MESSI DAD" can be used to remember the disorders included in the mhGAP program:

 

  • M: Mental disorders in children (Option A)
  • E: Epilepsy
  • S: Suicide
  • S: Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders (Option B)
  • I: Illicit drug use disorders
  • D: Depression (Option D)
  • A: Alcohol-related disorders
  • D: Dementia

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not included in the list of target conditions under the mhGAP program, which is why it is the correct answer to this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

Enterococci are gram-positive bacteria, and the first-line treatment for enterococcal infections is typically ampicillin. However, in patients with penicillin allergies, vancomycin is the preferred alternative. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including enterococci. It works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis, leading to bacterial cell death.

 

 

  • Linezolid               
  • Tigecycline (Complicated Skin/Intra-abdominal Infections)
  • Daptomycin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: This is a monobactam antibiotic that is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria particularly in community-acquired pneumonia in ICU patients with a penicillin allergy, Aztreonam is the best choice.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. While effective against some gram-positive bacteria, it is not the preferred choice for enterococcal infections, especially in patients with penicillin allergies due to the risk of cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: This is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. It would not be safe to use in a patient with a penicillin allergy due to the risk of a severe allergic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with penicillin allergies who have enterococcal infections, vancomycin is the preferred and safe alternative for treatment.

questions.text: Structure lies in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle all except (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tail of caudate nucleus

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn, not the floor.

 

Roof of Inferior horn - Tapetum (part of the corpus callosum), medial part of tail of the Caudate Nucleus and Striate Terminus

 

Floor of Inferior horn – Fimbria, hippocampus, collateral sulcus and collateral eminence.

 

Other Options:

 

The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is a part of the brain located in the temporal lobe. Structures found in the floor of the inferior horn include the hippocampus, fimbria, and collateral eminence.

 

Option A. Collateral eminence: This is a ridge in the floor of the inferior horn formed by the collateral sulcus.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: A crucial structure for memory conversion, located in the floor of the inferior horn.

 

Option C. Fimbria: A bundle of nerve fibers on the hippocampus that forms part of the floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, not in the floor.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used in the treatment of hemophilia B? (multiple choice) (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a)  Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP)
b)  Cryoprecipitate
c)  Factor VIII concentrates
d)  Cryo poor Plasma
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a & d

 

Explanation

 

Hemophilia B is a genetic bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of factor IX. The primary treatment for hemophilia B involves the replacement of the missing factor IX.

 

Treatment Options: Factor IX concentrates: The specific treatment for hemophilia B is the administration of factor IX concentrates, which directly replace the deficient clotting factor.

 

a. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP): FFP contains all the clotting factors, including factor IX, in certain proportions. It can be used as a treatment for hemophilia B, especially in situations where factor IX concentrates are not available. FFP serves as a "poor man's alternative" due to its comprehensive content of clotting factors.

 

d. Cryopoor Plasma: This is FFP from which the cryoprecipitate has been removed. While cryoprecipitate contains high levels of factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibrinogen, the cryopoor plasma retains significant amounts of factor IX. Therefore, cryopoor plasma can be used as an alternative treatment for hemophilia B. (preferred over FFP)

 

Other Options:

 

b. Cryoprecipitate: This blood product is enriched with factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibrinogen but contains little to no factor IX, making it unsuitable for treating hemophilia B.

 

c. Factor VIII concentrates: This treatment is specific to hemophilia A, which is caused by a deficiency of factor VIII. It is not effective for hemophilia B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of hemophilia B primarily involves the administration of factor IX concentrates. Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) and cryopoor plasma are also viable options due to their content of factor IX. Factor VIII concentrates and cryoprecipitate are not suitable for hemophilia B as they do not contain significant levels of factor IX.

questions.text: Identify the device in the image: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PEG tube

 

The image provided shows a tray containing various instruments, including an introducer, a tube with a bolster, and a guide wire, which are characteristic of a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube kit. A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food. The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach. The presence of these components in the tray confirms that the  is a PEG tube. This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it, which is why the tray includes various tools for this process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube): An NJ tube is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube (Nasogastric tube): An NG tube is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube: A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit. Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNS

 

DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is the fluid of choice in pediatric patients. It contains 5% dextrose along with normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride). This combination helps to provide both hydration and glucose, which is essential for energy. Additionally, DNS can help maintain electrolyte balance, which is critical in pediatric patients who are often at risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. In practice, 1 ml of potassium chloride (KCl) is often added to every 100 ml of DNS to ensure adequate potassium levels, which are vital for proper cellular function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RL (Ringer's Lactate): Ringer's Lactate is often used for fluid resuscitation in adults and in specific conditions such as acidosis. However, it does not contain dextrose, which is necessary for pediatric patients for energy and maintaining blood glucose levels.

 

Option C. NS (Normal Saline): Normal Saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is useful for hydration and electrolyte balance but lacks dextrose. Pediatric patients need a source of glucose, especially in cases of prolonged fasting or illness, making NS alone less suitable than DNS.

 

Option D. 5% dextrose: 5% dextrose provides glucose but lacks the electrolytes found in saline. This can lead to imbalances, particularly in pediatric patients, where maintaining proper electrolyte levels is crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fluid of choice in pediatric patients is DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline), which provides essential hydration, electrolytes, and glucose for energy.

questions.text: A female with breast cancer undergoes investigation which reveals the presence of ER positivity. Presence of ER is important as it is a:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Predictive marker

 

Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity in breast cancer is primarily used as a predictive marker. The presence of ER indicates that the cancer cells are likely to respond to hormonal therapies such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. These therapies work by blocking estrogen receptors or decreasing estrogen levels in the body, which helps slow or stop the growth of ER-positive breast cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic marker: The presence of ER is not used to diagnose breast cancer, as normal breast tissue can also express estrogen receptors. Therefore, ER positivity alone cannot confirm a diagnosis of breast cancer.

 

Option B. Prognostic marker: While ER status can provide some prognostic information, such as indicating a potentially better outcome due to responsiveness to hormone therapy, it is not solely used for prognosis. Prognostic factors typically include tumor size, lymph node status, and other molecular markers.

 

Option D. Surrogate molecular marker: A surrogate molecular marker is used as a substitute for a clinical endpoint. ER positivity does not serve as a surrogate molecular marker in this context; instead, it directly informs the treatment approach and potential response to therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER positivity in breast cancer is a predictive marker that helps determine the likelihood of response to hormonal therapies, making it crucial for guiding treatment decisions.

 

Additional classification:

questions.text: Most potent biological Estrogen: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estradiol

 

Explanation:

 

Estrogens are a group of steroid hormones that play a crucial role in the regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the different forms of estrogen, estradiol (E2) is the most potent and biologically active. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the dominant form of estrogen during the reproductive years.

 

Estradiol binds with the highest affinity to estrogen receptors compared to other forms like estrone and estriol, which is why it exerts the most potent biological effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrone: Estrone (E1) is less potent than estradiol and is the primary form of estrogen after menopause. It has a weaker affinity for estrogen receptors and thus, exerts less biological activity.

 

Option C. Estriol: Estriol (E3) is the weakest of the three primary estrogens. It is primarily produced during pregnancy and has the least biological activity due to its low affinity for estrogen receptors.

 

Option D. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogens are a mixture of several types of estrogens, typically used in hormone replacement therapy. They are not as biologically potent as estradiol when considered individually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent biological estrogen.

choices.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.text: A patient presents with a foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complains of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step of management in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Irrigation of eye with normal saline

 

 

 

The initial management for any chemical injury to the eye, including chuna (lime) exposure, is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline. This step is crucial to wash out the chemical substance from the eye to minimize further damage. Immediate irrigation helps dilute and remove the chemical agent, reducing the risk of severe injury to the ocular tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics drops in eye: Antibiotic drops are important to prevent infection after the initial management, but they are not the first step. Irrigation must be done first to remove the chemical irritant.

 

Option B. Temporary tarsorrhaphy: Temporary tarsorrhaphy involves partially sewing the eyelids together to protect the eye, but this is not appropriate in the acute phase of a chemical injury. The eye needs to remain open to allow thorough irrigation and drainage of the chemical substance.

 

Option D. Complete Scraping: Complete scraping is a procedure to remove foreign particles embedded in the eye. While this might be necessary if there are chunks of chuna embedded in the conjunctiva, it is not the first step. The initial priority is to irrigate the eye to remove as much of the chemical as possible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first step in the management of chemical injuries to the eye is immediate and copious irrigation with normal saline to wash out the chemical substance

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

 

Heme catabolism is the process by which the heme portion of hemoglobin is broken down. This process begins with the degradation of heme into biliverdin, which is subsequently reduced to bilirubin. This bilirubin is further processed into conjugated bilirubin, urobilinogen, and stercobilinogen. In addition to these products, heme catabolism also generates carbon monoxide and ferrous ion (Fe²⁺).

 

Aminolaevulinic acid, on the other hand, is not a product of heme catabolism but is instead an important precursor in the synthesis of heme. It is formed in the first step of heme synthesis, where succinyl-CoA and glycine combine under the action of the enzyme aminolaevulinic acid synthase.

 

Therefore, while ferrous ion, biliverdin, and carbon monoxide are products of heme catabolism, aminolaevulinic acid is involved in heme synthesis and not in its breakdown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous ion: This is indeed a product of heme catabolism, as iron is released during the breakdown of the heme group.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is one of the direct products of heme degradation, and it is subsequently reduced to bilirubin.

 

Option D. Carbon monoxide: This is another product of heme catabolism, and notably, heme catabolism is the only process in the human body where carbon monoxide is produced endogenously.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the management of type 2 diabetes is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor used in the management of type 2 diabetes mellitus. SGLT2 inhibitors work by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in the urine. This mechanism of action results in a higher concentration of glucose in the urinary tract, which can promote bacterial growth and lead to an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: This drug is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity but is not associated with an increased risk of UTIs. Instead, it can cause side effects such as fluid retention, weight gain, and an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels in the bloodstream. It is associated with risks such as pancreatitis and gastrointestinal disturbances but not with an increased risk of UTIs.

 

Option D. Metformin: This is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. Common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances (e.g., diarrhea) and vitamin B12 deficiency, but it does not increase the risk of UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This highlights the importance of monitoring for UTIs in patients prescribed this medication.

choices.text: Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism
Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with proximal weakness, lethargy, low/depressed mood, and recurrent renal stones. Laboratory testing revealed a normal S. Calcium and increased PTH levels. What is the organ involved and the pathology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid gland and hyperparathyroidism

 

The clinical presentation of proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones, combined with laboratory findings of normal serum calcium and increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, is indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism is typically associated with hypercalcemia, but there is a variant known as normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism. In this condition, patients exhibit elevated PTH levels while maintaining normal serum calcium levels.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Proximal Weakness and Lethargy: Common symptoms of hyperparathyroidism due to muscle weakness and fatigue.
  • Low/Depressed Mood: Psychiatric manifestations are frequently seen in hyperparathyroidism.
  • Recurrent Renal Stones: Hyperparathyroidism leads to increased calcium excretion, resulting in kidney stones.
  • Normal Serum Calcium and Increased PTH: In normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism, PTH levels are elevated, but serum calcium levels remain within the normal range.

 

This condition is a diagnosis of exclusion, meaning other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism (e.g., vitamin D deficiency, chronic kidney disease) must be ruled out first. Given the absence of clinical findings suggesting vitamin deficiency, osteomalacia, or chronic kidney disease in this case, normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thyroid and Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism does not present with the combination of symptoms and laboratory findings described.

 

Option C. Adrenal and Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma typically presents with episodic hypertension, headaches, and palpitations, not the symptoms and lab findings described.

 

Option D. Bone and Metabolic Bone Disease: While metabolic bone diseases can cause weakness and other symptoms, they do not typically present with elevated PTH and normal calcium as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normocalcemic primary hyperparathyroidism presents with normal serum calcium and elevated PTH levels and is associated with symptoms like proximal weakness, lethargy, low mood, and recurrent renal stones. It is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising. What is the likely underlying condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypercortisolism

 

Hypercortisolism, also known as Cushing's syndrome, is characterized by an excess of cortisol in the body. The clinical features of Cushing's syndrome include weight gain, particularly in the face, neck, and trunk, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae (stretch marks), and easy bruising. These symptoms are a result of the catabolic effects of cortisol on various tissues.

 

  • Weight Gain: Cortisol promotes the deposition of fat in specific areas, leading to central obesity.
  • Proximal Muscle Weakness: Cortisol has catabolic effects on muscle tissue, leading to muscle wasting and weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles.
  • Purple Striae: Cortisol weakens the skin by breaking down collagen, leading to the formation of purple striae.
  • Easy Bruising: Cortisol reduces the ability of blood vessels to repair themselves, causing increased bruising.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: This condition involves an excess of thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms such as weight loss, increased appetite, heat intolerance, and hyperactivity. It does not typically cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: This condition involves an excess of parathyroid hormone, leading to hypercalcemia, bone pain, kidney stones, and abdominal pain. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Hyperaldosteronism: This condition involves an excess of aldosterone, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's syndrome, or hypercortisolism, is characterized by weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising due to the catabolic effects of excess cortisol.

choices.text: Dapsone
Ofloxacin
Rifampicin
Clofazimine

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of leprosy can result in hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Clofazimine is a drug used in the treatment of leprosy that is known to cause hyperpigmentation as a side effect. This hyperpigmentation can affect the skin, resulting in a reddish-brown to nearly black discoloration. The effect is not limited to the skin; it can also cause discoloration of body fluids such as sweat and urine, potentially leading to staining of clothing.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Incorrect as Dapsone, while used in leprosy treatment, is not typically associated with hyperpigmentation.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Incorrect because Ofloxacin, an antibiotic used in some leprosy treatment regimens, does not cause hyperpigmentation as a common side effect.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Incorrect as Rifampicin, though it can cause orange-red discoloration of urine and other body fluids, is not associated with skin hyperpigmentation in the way clofazimine is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clofazimine, a drug used in leprosy treatment, can cause significant hyperpigmentation of the skin and discoloration of body fluids, which can be an important consideration in patient counseling and management.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic is correctly matched with its site of action (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal tubule

 

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - These act in the proximal tubule. Acetazolamide is a commonly used carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics- Collecting duct: These work primarily in the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle, not the collecting duct. Mannitol is a common example.

 

Option C. Thiazides-Loop of Henle: These primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide is a typical example.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists- early Distal tubules: These work in the collecting ducts and late distal tubules. Spironolactone is a well-known aldosterone antagonist.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) used as an anabolic (bone-building) agent in the treatment of osteoporosis. It is administered via daily subcutaneous injections. While effective in increasing bone mass and reducing fracture risk, the long-term use of teriparatide has been associated with certain risks.

 

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been linked to the long-term use of teriparatide in animal studies. Specifically, when used for more than two years, there is evidence from these studies suggesting an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. This potential risk has led to a restriction on the duration of teriparatide therapy to a maximum of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: This condition is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonates, not teriparatide. Bisphosphonates can lead to decreased blood flow to the jawbone, causing osteonecrosis, especially following dental procedures.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture (atypical femoral fracture): This type of fracture is also associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, rather than teriparatide. Bisphosphonates may alter bone remodeling, leading to atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that actually increases bone mass. Bisphosphonates also prevent bone mass loss by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Thus, loss of bone mass is not associated with either teriparatide or bisphosphonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.
