questions.text: Match the blood product with the shelf life mentioned in the next column: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-1, C-4, D-2

 

The shelf lives of various blood products are crucial for ensuring their efficacy and safety in clinical use. Here is the matching of blood products with their respective shelf lives:

 

Single donor platelet (A): These typically have a shelf life of 5 days (3.).

 

Packed red blood cells (B): These can be stored for up to 42 days depending on the preservative used (1.).

 

Cryoprecipitate (C): This blood product has a shelf life of 1 year when stored properly (4.).

 

Granulocyte concentrate (D): This product has a short shelf life of 24 hours (2.).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The shelf life of different blood products is essential for proper storage and timely usage in medical practice.

 

  • Single donor platelet - 5 days
  • Packed red blood cells - 42 days
  • Cryoprecipitate - 1 year
  • Granulocyte concentrate - 24 hours

choices.text: Androgen insensitivity Syndrome

questions.text: 16-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination she has well developed secondary sexual characters and labs revealed a normal LH and FSH. Her karyotype is 46XX. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mullerian Agenesis

 

Mullerian agenesis, also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, is the most likely diagnosis for this patient. The key features supporting this diagnosis are:

 

  1. Primary amenorrhea in a 16-year-old girl
  2. Well-developed secondary sexual characters
  3. Normal LH and FSH levels
  4. 46,XX karyotype

 

In Mullerian agenesis, the uterus and upper vagina fail to develop properly, but the ovaries function normally. This explains the presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal hormone levels, despite the absence of menstruation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Gonadal Dyagenesis: Incorrect because patients with gonadal dysgenesis typically have high FSH and LH levels due to lack of negative feedback from functioning gonads. They also often lack secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option C. Kallmann Syndrome: Incorrect, isolated GnRH deficiency which is characterized by low LH and FSH levels, absent secondary sexual characteristics, and often associated with anosmia (loss of smell). The patient in this case has normal hormone levels and well-developed secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: Incorrect because this condition has a 46,XY karyotype, not 46,XX as in this case. Additionally, individuals with complete AIS would present with female external genitalia but lack a uterus and ovaries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome) presents with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, normal hormone levels (LH and FSH), and a 46,XX karyotype.

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin
Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+
Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum
Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

 

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is characterized by the presence of Reed Sternberg cells, which are of B cell origin. These cells typically express CD30 and PAX 5 markers. The nodular sclerosis subtype of HL often involves the mediastinum, where Reed Sternberg cells are referred to as lacunar cells due to their unique appearance in this subtype. However, the statement that the commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring is incorrect. The Waldeyer ring is more commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). HL typically affects the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells, the hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma, originate from B cells.

 

Option B. Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells express CD30 and PAX 5 markers, which are used in diagnosing Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum: Correct. The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma frequently involves the mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin lymphoma typically involves the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. The involvement of the Waldeyer ring is more characteristic of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: Identify the crystal in a patient with urinary pH of 8.7: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple Phosphate

 

Normally, urinary pH typically ranges from 4.4 to 6.5, which is acidic.

 

Here, an alkaline urinary pH of 8.7 promotes the formation of certain types of crystals, particularly triple phosphate (struvite) and calcium phosphate crystals. The image provided shows typical "coffin-lid" shaped crystals, which are characteristic of triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) or struvite crystals.

 

Triple Phosphate crystals are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Ureaplasma urealyticum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium Oxalate : These crystals typically form in acidic urine and have different shapes, such as envelope or dumbbell shapes.

 

Option C. Cystine : These crystals also form in acidic urine and have a distinctive hexagonal shape.

 

Option D. Uric Acid : These crystals form in acidic urine and appear as rhomboid or rosette shapes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple phosphate (struvite) crystals are associated with alkaline urine and have a "coffin-lid" appearance. They are commonly seen in patients with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive organisms.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

The correct answer is Mutation of tRNA. A suppressor mutation, specifically a tRNA mutation, can reverse the effect of an earlier mutation that produced a premature stop codon. In this scenario, the tRNA undergoes a mutation that allows it to recognize the stop codon (UAA in this case) as if it were a normal codon (e.g., serine's codon UCA). This suppressor tRNA can then insert an amino acid at the site of the stop codon, allowing protein synthesis to continue. This compensates for the earlier mutation that would have led to a truncated, non-functional protein, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene: This type of mutation typically disrupts the reading frame of the gene, leading to widespread changes in the amino acid sequence from the point of mutation onward. It usually results in a non-functional protein and does not suppress the effects of another mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene: While adding a normal gene might help correct a phenotype by introducing a functional version of the gene, it does not qualify as a suppressor mutation. This option does not specifically address the reversal of a mutation at the molecular level in the same way as tRNA mutation does.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene: Deleting the mutant gene would remove the mutation but would not revert the phenotype to wild type by itself. It eliminates the gene's effect entirely rather than compensating for the mutation within the gene or another gene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suppressor mutations, particularly those in tRNA, can reverse the effects of a previous mutation by allowing protein synthesis to continue even when a premature stop codon is present, thereby restoring the normal (wild-type) phenotype.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most commonly seen with which of the following infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

  • Gonorrhea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is notorious for developing resistance to multiple classes of antibiotics, including penicillins, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and most recently, some strains have shown reduced susceptibility to cephalosporins and azithromycin. Drug-resistant gonorrhea is a significant public health challenge, and the CDC recommends dual therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin to address this issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. While there have been cases of antibiotic resistance, it is not as prevalent or significant as in gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis (granuloma inguinale) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It is relatively rare, and drug resistance has not been a major issue in its treatment.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. While there are concerns about resistance to some antibiotics, such as macrolides, penicillin remains highly effective, and resistance is not as significant a problem as in gonorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, gonorrhea is the infection most commonly associated with drug resistance, making it a critical concern in the treatment of STIs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting. Upon further investigation, arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals the following: pH: 7.55, PCO2: 50 mmHg, HCO3-: 44 mmol/L. Given these findings, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

The ABG analysis reveals a pH of 7.55, indicating alkalosis (normal pH range: 7.35-7.45). The elevated bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 44 mmol/L (normal range: 22-28 mmol/L) points towards a metabolic origin for the alkalosis. In metabolic alkalosis, the kidneys retain bicarbonate, leading to an increase in serum bicarbonate levels.

 

Additionally, the elevated PCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) of 50 mmHg (normal range: 35-45 mmHg) indicates a compensatory respiratory response. In metabolic alkalosis, the body attempts to compensate by hypoventilation, which increases PCO2 to counteract the rise in pH.

 

  • pH 7.55: Indicates alkalosis.
  • PCO2 50 mmHg: Elevated, indicating respiratory compensation.
  • HCO3- 44 mmol/L: Elevated, indicating a metabolic cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory Acidosis: This condition is characterized by a low pH and high PCO2 due to impaired ventilation, resulting in CO2 retention. The pH would be acidic, not alkalotic.

 

Option B. Respiratory Alkalosis: This condition involves a high pH and low PCO2 due to hyperventilation. However, in this case, PCO2 is elevated, not decreased.

 

Option C. Metabolic Acidosis: This condition involves a low pH and low bicarbonate levels due to an accumulation of acid or loss of bicarbonate. The pH here is alkalotic, not acidic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic alkalosis is characterized by an elevated pH and bicarbonate level, with respiratory compensation leading to increased PCO2.

choices.text: Commonly presents as an abdominal mass
Presents in children < 6 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Wilms’ tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

 

Wilms’ tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children, typically under the age of six. It is one of the most common pediatric solid tumors and presents with a variety of clinical features, most notably an abdominal mass.

 

  • Common Presentation: The most common presenting symptom of Wilms’ tumor is a painless abdominal mass, which may be noticed by the child's parents or during a routine physical examination. This aligns with option A, making it correct.
  • Age of Onset: Wilms’ tumor most frequently occurs in young children, particularly those under the age of six. This is well-documented in clinical practice and research, making option B correct.
  • Treatment and Prognosis: The treatment for Wilms’ tumor typically includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy. The majority of patients have a good prognosis and can recover with appropriate treatment, supporting option C as correct.
  • Lung Metastasis: Contrary to option D, lung metastasis is actually relatively common in Wilms’ tumor and often one of the first sites of metastasis. It is not rare, nor is it necessarily a late feature. Early detection and treatment of lung metastases are crucial in the management of Wilms' tumor, making this option incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly presents as an abdominal mass: This is a correct statement. Wilms’ tumor typically presents as an abdominal mass, which is often the first sign that prompts further investigation.

 

Option B. Presents in children < 6 years of age: This is also correct. The majority of cases occur in children under the age of six, making this a well-recognized feature of the disease.

 

Option C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy: This statement is accurate as well. Advances in chemotherapy and radiotherapy have significantly improved survival rates for patients with Wilms’ tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis in Wilms’ tumor is not rare; it is actually a common site of metastasis and often occurs early in the disease course.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is produced by: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Kidney
  2. Liver
  3. Spleen
  4. Lung
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin is a hormone primarily produced by the kidneys and to a lesser extent by the liver. In a healthy individual, the majority of erythropoietin (approximately 90%) is produced by the kidney, specifically by peritubular interstitial fibroblasts. These cells respond to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) by increasing the production of erythropoietin, which then stimulates the bone marrow to produce more red blood cells. The liver also contributes to erythropoietin production, particularly through sinusoidal cells, although it accounts for only about 10% of the hormone's production under normal conditions.

 

In certain pathological conditions, such as in some types of anemia (e.g., thalassemia major), the spleen may take on a role in erythropoietin production to compensate for the body's increased need for red blood cells. However, this is not the case in healthy individuals, which is why the spleen and other organs like the lung are not considered significant sources of erythropoietin under normal physiological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

3 and 4: While the spleen can contribute in pathological states, it is not a primary source under normal conditions, and the lung does not contribute to erythropoietin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys, with the liver contributing to a lesser extent. Understanding the primary and secondary sources of erythropoietin is crucial, particularly in the context of conditions affecting red blood cell production.

questions.text: All of the following drugs act as HER-1 inhibitors except (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pertuzumab

 

  • Pertuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets HER-2 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2), not HER-1. 
  • It is used primarily in the treatment of HER-2 positive breast cancer.
  • HER-1 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 1) is also known as EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor). 
  • Several monoclonal antibodies target EGFR, while others target different members of the HER family, such as HER-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetuximab: Cetuximab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of certain types of colorectal cancer and head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. Necitumumab: Necitumumab is also an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

 

Option D. Panitumumab: Panitumumab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.

 

Given this information, the drug that does not act as a HER-1 inhibitor is: 
c. Pertuzumab

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient underwent surgery under general anaesthesia. Rocuronium was used as a muscle relaxant during the procedure. After the surgery, the patient has not regained muscle function, indicating prolonged muscle paralysis. The medical team needs to reverse the effects of rocuronium quickly to ensure patient safety and recovery. Which of the following can result in the fastest reversal? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sugammadex

 

  • Sugammadex is a specific reversal agent for aminosteroid neuromuscular blocking agents such as rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the rocuronium molecules, rendering them inactive, and thus rapidly reversing the neuromuscular blockade. Sugammadex provides the fastest and most effective reversal of rocuronium-induced paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, competing with rocuronium. While effective, it is slower and less specific than sugammadex and can have more side effects.

 

Option C. Edrophonium: Edrophonium is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor but is less commonly used compared to neostigmine for reversing neuromuscular blockade. It is generally faster than neostigmine but still not as rapid or effective as sugammadex for rocuronium reversal.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade. It is an anticholinergic agent primarily used to counteract the muscarinic side effects of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine and edrophonium, such as bradycardia. It does not reverse muscle paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, sugammadex is the most effective and fastest-acting agent for reversing the effects of rocuronium, making it the best choice in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: Parthenogenesis is seen in which of the following worm?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

Parthenogenesis is a form of asexual reproduction where the female organism is capable of producing offspring without the need for fertilization by a male. In the case of parasitic worms, this phenomenon is specifically seen in Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Reference Paragraph Explanation:

 

  1. Strongyloides stercoralis: Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the nematodes because it can reproduce through parthenogenesis. This means that the female worms can produce fertile eggs without mating with a male. In the human host, only female Strongyloides worms are found in the intestine, and they are capable of producing eggs or larvae without male fertilization.
  2. Oviparous, Viviparous, and Oviviparous Nematodes:
    • Oviparous: These worms lay eggs which then develop outside the female’s body. Examples include Ascaris and Trichuris.
    • Viviparous: These worms give birth to live larvae. Examples include some species of Dracunculus and Wuchereria.
    • Oviviparous: These worms lay eggs that hatch immediately as they are laid, producing larvae. Strongyloides stercoralis is an example, as the eggs hatch into larvae almost immediately after being laid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichuris trichura: This worm is oviparous, meaning it lays eggs that develop and hatch outside the female’s body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is also an oviparous worm. It lays eggs that develop in the external environment.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Commonly known as pinworm, it is also oviparous, laying eggs that hatch outside the body. It does not reproduce via parthenogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parthenogenesis, where a female worm can produce offspring without male fertilization, is a unique reproductive strategy seen in Strongyloides stercoralis. This worm is also oviviparous, laying eggs that hatch almost immediately.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. An ECG was taken in the emergency and was shown. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior MI

 

The patient's ECG shows classic signs of a posterior myocardial infarction (MI). The characteristic features of posterior MI in leads V1, V2 and (±) V3 include a tall R wave, ST depression, and upright T wave. These features suggest a mirror image of an infarction in the posterior wall of the left ventricle. While definitive diagnosis of a posterior MI typically involves additional leads (V7, V8, V9), the observed patterns in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of this condition.

 

In the provided case, the absence of ST elevation rules out an acute STEMI. NSTEMI and unstable angina can only be differentiated by cardiac biomarkers such as troponins, which are not mentioned here. Acute myocarditis would typically present with non-specific ECG changes and a relevant clinical history, such as a recent viral infection, which is not present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSTEMI:  NSTEMI (Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction) can present with similar symptoms but requires positive cardiac troponins for diagnosis. The absence of troponin data makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option B. Unstable Angina: Unstable angina presents with similar symptoms but without elevation of cardiac biomarkers. As mentioned, differentiating between NSTEMI and unstable angina is not possible without troponin levels, which are not provided.

 

Option D. Acute Myocarditis: Acute myocarditis would typically present with a history of viral infection and can show non-specific ECG changes, often including sinus tachycardia. The patient's history and ECG findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of tall R waves, ST depression, and upright T waves in leads V2 and V3 are indicative of a posterior myocardial infarction.

questions.text: Which will you not see in twin pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic)

 

The correct answer is MADC (Monoamniotic Dichorionic). The classification of twin pregnancies is based on the timing of the zygote's division and the resulting structures, such as the number of chorions (placentas) and amnions (amniotic sacs) that form.

 

  • Dichorionic Diamniotic (DCDA) twins occur when the division happens very early (within the first 72 hours after fertilization), resulting in two separate chorions and amnions.
  • Monochorionic Diamniotic (MCDA) twins occur when the division happens between the 4th and 8th day after fertilization, after the chorion has formed but before the amniotic sac has split.
  • Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA) twins result from division that occurs between the 9th and 12th day after fertilization, after both the chorion and amnion have formed, leading to two embryos sharing a single amniotic sac and a single chorion.
  • Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible scenario. The formation of a single amnion with two separate chorions (placentas) does not occur because the chorion forms before the amnion. Thus, this combination is anatomically and developmentally impossible.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. MCMA (Monochorionic Monoamniotic): This is a recognized type of twin pregnancy where twins share both the chorion and the amnion.

 

Option B. MCDA (Monochorionic Diamniotic): Another recognized type, where twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs.

 

Option D. DADC (Dichorionic Diamniotic): This is the most common type of twin pregnancy, especially in dizygotic (fraternal) twins, where each twin has its own chorion and amnion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamniotic Dichorionic (MADC) is not a possible configuration in twin pregnancies. The formation of the amnion and chorion follows a specific sequence that does not allow for this combination. Understanding the timing and resulting structures of zygote division is crucial in determining the type of twin pregnancy.

questions.text: A young girl presents with retention of urine and cyclical abdominal pain. On examination, there is a tense bluish bulge seen at the introitus. The diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imperforate hymen

 

An imperforate hymen is a congenital disorder where the hymen, a thin membrane that typically surrounds or partially covers the vaginal opening, completely obstructs the vaginal opening. This condition can lead to the accumulation of menstrual blood within the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), resulting in cyclical abdominal pain and urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder.

 

The classic presentation includes:

 

  • Cyclical abdominal pain: This occurs as menstrual blood accumulates but cannot exit the body, leading to distension and discomfort.
  • Retention of urine: The accumulated blood can exert pressure on the bladder and urethra, causing difficulty in urination.
  • Tense bluish bulge at the introitus: This is a distinctive finding in imperforate hymen, where the accumulated blood stretches the hymen, causing it to appear bluish and bulging at the vaginal opening.

 

The treatment for an imperforate hymen typically involves making a cruciate incision in the hymen to drain the accumulated blood (hematocolpos) and relieve the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transverse vaginal septum: This condition involves a fibrous or muscular wall across the vagina, which can also cause symptoms similar to an imperforate hymen, such as hematocolpos and urinary retention. However, it does not usually present with the characteristic tense bluish bulge at the introitus because the septum is thicker and the blood does not push against the hymen.

 

Option C. Vertical vaginal septum: A vertical vaginal septum is a partition that divides the vaginal canal into two parts. While it may lead to reproductive issues or dyspareunia, it typically does not cause urinary retention or cyclical pain as described in this case, nor does it present with a bluish bulge.

 

Option D. Mullerian agenesis: This is a congenital absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper part of the vagina. Patients with this condition often present with primary amenorrhea but do not typically have cyclical abdominal pain or urinary retention. Additionally, there would be no bluish bulge at the introitus because there is no accumulation of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of cyclical abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a tense bluish bulge at the introitus in a young girl strongly suggests an imperforate hymen. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glycosylation

 

The correct answer is Glycosylation. Glycosylation is a process where sugars are added to proteins or lipids, but it occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, primarily during and after translation, not during post-transcriptional modifications. Post-transcriptional modifications occur to RNA molecules after they have been transcribed from DNA but before they are translated into proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylation: Methylation in the context of RNA processing involves the addition of a methyl group, often to the 5' end of the RNA as part of the capping process. For example, a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end of the RNA to protect it from degradation and assist in ribosome binding during translation.

 

Option B. Endonuclease cleavage: This is part of the splicing process where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA. Endonucleases cut within the nucleotide sequence, helping to remove non-coding sequences (introns) from the RNA transcript.

 

Option C. Capping: This process involves adding a modified guanine nucleotide (7-methylguanosine) to the 5' end of the RNA. This cap protects the RNA from degradation and is essential for the initiation of translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycosylation is not a post-transcriptional modification. Post-transcriptional modifications include processes like capping, methylation, and splicing, which are critical for the maturation of mRNA before it is translated into protein.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of bipedal edema? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic Venous Insufficiency

 

Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) typically leads to asymmetric leg swelling, where one leg is more affected than the other. In cases of CVI, the swelling is often unilateral, and if bilateral, it is usually asymmetric. This makes it the least common cause of bipedal (symmetric) edema among the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupus Nephritis: This condition affects the kidneys, leading to fluid retention and typically causing bilateral leg swelling. It is a common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option C. Heart Failure: This systemic condition causes the heart to pump blood inefficiently, leading to fluid buildup in the lower extremities and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic Liver Disease: This condition results in decreased protein synthesis and portal hypertension, causing fluid retention and symmetric bipedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency typically causes unilateral or asymmetric leg swelling, making it the least common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

choices.text: Thin smear with acridine orange
Thin smear with Giemsa

questions.text: Best investigation for malaria speciation identification - (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for malaria species identification. This technique provides a single layer of red blood cells (RBCs), allowing for clear visualization of the parasite's morphology. The Giemsa stain enhances the visibility of the parasite's features, making it easier to distinguish between different Plasmodium species based on their characteristic appearances within the RBCs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Thick smear: While useful for screening and detecting the presence of malaria parasites, thick smears contain multiple layers of RBCs and often deform the cells. This makes it difficult to accurately identify specific Plasmodium species.

 

Option B. Thin smear with acridine orange: This method, also known as the Kawamoto technique, stains only nucleic acids. While it highlights the parasites, it doesn't stain the RBCs, making it challenging to observe the parasite's relationship to the host cell and thus complicating species identification. (screening test)

 

Option D. Buffy Coat: This is a modified acridine orange-based test using a capillary tube instead of a slide. It's primarily a screening method to detect the presence of malaria parasites but is not suitable for species identification. (screening test)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin blood smears stained with Giemsa are the gold standard for malaria species identification due to their ability to clearly show parasite morphology within a single layer of RBCs.

questions.text: Which of the following STD is transmitted by all components of the blood?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Syphilis is a sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It can be transmitted through various means, including sexual contact, from mother to child during childbirth, and through blood transfusions. Syphilis can be transmitted by all components of the blood, making it a comprehensive risk in blood transfusion contexts.

 

While other infections like hepatitis B and C, malaria, and HIV can also be transmitted through blood transfusions, the question specifically asks for an STD. Among the options given, syphilis is the only STD that fits this criterion.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis: Incorrect because while hepatitis B and C can be transmitted through blood transfusions, they are not classified primarily as sexually transmitted diseases.

 

Option B. Filariasis: Incorrect because filariasis is a parasitic disease transmitted by mosquitoes, not through blood transfusions or as an STD.

 

Option C. Malaria: Incorrect because malaria is a parasitic infection transmitted by mosquitoes and through blood transfusions, but it is not an STD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is an STD that can be transmitted by all components of the blood, highlighting the importance of thorough blood screening.

questions.text: A middle-aged housewife consumed rodenticide powder and presented with K+ levels of 2.5meq. On examination, irregular pulse with muscle paralysis is present. ECG shows ventricular ectopics. What is the suspected poison? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Barium carbonate

 

The above clinical scenario with a presentation of hypokalemia, cardiac arrhythmia, and paralysis after consumption of rodenticide poison is caused by Barium carbonate.

 

Barium carbonate is used in rat poison and acts as a local corrosive irritant that, after absorption, primarily affects the muscles, including the heart muscles.

 

  • The initial symptoms manifest as gastrointestinal distress like nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • It subsequently progresses to muscle cramps, stiffness, pupil dilation, paralysis of the tongue and larynx, and vertigo.
  • The early impact on the heart can lead to increased blood pressure, slow and irregular pulse, and in severe cases, potential cardiac arrest.
  • Notable changes also include loss of reflexes and muscle paralysis.

 

Treatment involves:

 

  1. Gastric lavage to remove the contents and administration of either sodium sulfate or magnesium sulfate solution to precipitate the barium as an insoluble sulfate.
  2. Intravenous administration of 10 mL of 10% sodium sulfate every 15 minutes to convert the soluble barium salt into insoluble sulfate.
  3. Purging with magnesium sulfate and repeated bowel lavage.
  4. Symptomatic management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aluminium phosphide (ALP): This is a solid fumigant pesticide and rodenticide that releases phosphine gas, a toxic agent, which leads to inhibition of the electron transport chain and severe toxicity. It does not cause hypokalemia but causes other symptoms like cardiac arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, and death due to cardiogenic shock.

 

Option B. Zinc phosphide: This rodenticide can cause symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. However, its toxicity is generally less severe compared to aluminium phosphide, but it does not cause the hypokalemia seen in the clinical presentation.

 

Option D. Warfarin tablets: Warfarin is an anticoagulant used in some rat poisons, but it is not associated with hypokalemia. It acts primarily by affecting clotting factors, leading to bleeding tendencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barium carbonate poisoning leads to hypokalemia, muscle paralysis, and cardiac arrhythmias, requiring urgent treatment with gastric lavage and sulfate administration to prevent fatal complications.

questions.text: What is anisometropia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Difference in refractive error

 

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error (i.e., the focusing power) between the two eyes. This difference can cause each eye to focus differently, leading to difficulties in binocular vision and sometimes resulting in amblyopia (lazy eye) if one eye is significantly more affected than the other.

 

  1. ANISOMETROPIA: Difference between Refractive Error of two eyes
  2. ANISEIKONIA: Difference between Image size in two eyes
  3. ANISOCORIA: Difference between Pupil size of two eyes
  4. ANISOPIA: Difference between vision of two eyes

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Difference in color of iris: Incorrect. This condition is called heterochromia, not anisometropia. Heterochromia refers to a difference in coloration, typically of the iris.

 

Option C. Difference in axial length: Incorrect. While differences in axial length can contribute to anisometropia, the term itself specifically refers to differences in refractive error, not just axial length.

 

Option D. Difference in visual acuity: Incorrect. Although anisometropia can lead to differences in visual acuity between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to the difference in refractive error, not visual acuity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anisometropia is defined as a difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, which can lead to difficulties in binocular vision and potentially cause amblyopia in the more affected eye.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric test?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

The RBC pipette, identifiable by its red bead, is primarily used for counting red blood cells in a blood sample. It is not suitable for the colorimetric estimation of hemoglobin, as it is not designed for colorimetric comparisons or for mixing the reagents involved in this method.

 

Other Options:

 

The colorimetric method for hemoglobin estimation, often referred to as Sahli's method, relies on comparing the color intensity of a hemoglobin solution to a standard comparator. The primary steps involve mixing a blood sample with N/10 HCl in a graduated hemoglobin tube, which then undergoes color comparison against a brown glass standard.

 

Key Tools Used in Sahli's Method:

 

Option B. Sahli graduated hemoglobin tube: Used to mix blood with hydrochloric acid and measure the resulting color intensity.

 

Option C. Comparator with brown glass standard: Helps in comparing the color of the hemoglobin solution to determine the concentration.

 

Option D. Hemoglobin pipette: Utilized to accurately measure and transfer the blood sample into the graduated hemoglobin tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric (Sahli's) method, as it is designed for cell counting rather than for the preparation and color comparison required in this test.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: In triage, immediately life-threatening injury is categorized as what color code? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In the triage system, which is used to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code. This indicates that the patient requires immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications. The Red category is the highest priority in triage, where intervention is needed within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Green: This color code is used for ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment.

 

Option C. Yellow: The Yellow category is for urgent cases where intervention is required within 6 to 24 hours. While these patients need prompt attention, their condition is not as immediately critical as those in the Red category.

 

Option D. Black: The Black category is reserved for patients who are either deceased or moribund (those who are unlikely to survive). This represents the lowest priority in triage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a triage situation, an immediately life-threatening injury is classified under the Red color code, indicating the need for urgent medical intervention.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have polysaccharide vaccine?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis B

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are typically made from the polysaccharide capsule that surrounds certain bacteria. These vaccines are designed to protect against bacterial infections by inducing immunity against the polysaccharide antigens present in the capsule.

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant vaccine that uses a portion of the hepatitis B virus (HBsAg - hepatitis B surface antigen) produced in yeast cells. This vaccine does not involve a polysaccharide component as the hepatitis B virus does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal: The pneumococcal vaccine is available in both polysaccharide (PPSV23) and conjugate forms (PCV13), targeting the polysaccharide capsule of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option B. Meningococcal: Meningococcal vaccines also include polysaccharide (MPSV4) and conjugate forms (MCV4), aimed at the polysaccharide capsule of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a conjugate vaccine that includes the polysaccharide antigen from the bacterial capsule conjugated to a protein carrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine, as it targets a virus that does not have a polysaccharide capsule.

questions.text: A female presented with an ulcerated breast lump. Nipple retraction was seen, with some warmth and redness. On biopsy, it was diagnosed as invasive ductal carcinoma. According to AJCC 8th Ed., which of these correctly represents the stage? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T4b

 

In the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) 8th edition staging system, the classification of breast cancer stages is detailed based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and the presence of metastasis.

 

The presentation of an ulcerated breast lump, nipple retraction, warmth, and redness suggests skin involvement, which is characteristic of a T4 classification. Specifically, the presence of ulceration and skin involvement corresponds to T4b. T4b is used when there is skin involvement in the form of ulceration, satellite skin nodules, or peau d’orange (skin changes resembling the texture of an orange).

 

While there is the possibility of inflammatory breast cancer due to the warmth and redness, the key feature here is ulceration, which is more indicative of T4b. Inflammatory breast cancer would correspond to a T4d classification, characterized by more extensive skin changes like diffuse erythema and edema (peau d'orange) involving more than one-third of the breast, often with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IV with N1-N2 involvement: This is incorrect as there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M1), which is required for a Stage IV classification. The presence of regional lymph node involvement (N1-N2) alone does not justify a Stage IV classification.

 

Option C. Stage IIIB: This could be considered if the case were inflammatory breast cancer, but based on the ulceration and other features described, T4b is more appropriate unless additional evidence of inflammatory changes was present.

 

Option D. It cannot be M1: This statement is partially correct as the case does not mention any distant metastasis (M1), but it doesn’t address the primary tumor stage, which is the focus of the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulceration of a breast lump with skin involvement typically corresponds to T4b in the AJCC 8th edition staging system for breast cancer. It is essential to differentiate between T4b and T4d (inflammatory breast cancer) based on the clinical presentation and pathological findings.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with left facial weakness. Routine lab workup was normal. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The presentation of left facial weakness with normal routine lab workup suggests Bell's palsy, an idiopathic condition characterized by sudden onset of unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion and is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis.

 

Corticosteroids: The first-line treatment for Bell's palsy is corticosteroids. They are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. Early treatment with corticosteroids can significantly improve the chances of complete recovery. A typical regimen is prednisolone or prednisone.

 

Dosage: Prednisone 60-80 mg per day for 5-7 days, followed by a taper over the next 5-7 days.

 

Note – In the severity grading system, House-Brackmann grading, if the patient has Grade 4 or Grade 5 severity, consider adding antivirals such as acyclovir or valacyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Although acyclovir or other antiviral agents like valacyclovir are sometimes used, their benefit is less clear. They may be considered in severe cases of Bell's palsy, particularly when there is a suspicion of herpes simplex virus involvement, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Dosage: Valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days or acyclovir 400 mg five times a day for 7-10 days.

 

Note - Valacyclovir has superior bioavailability, superior efficacy, and lower side effects compared to acyclovir.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: There is no role for antibiotics in the treatment of Bell's palsy as it is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Physiotherapy: While physiotherapy, including facial exercises and eye protection measures, can be supportive, it is not the primary treatment and should be considered an adjunct to corticosteroid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best initial management for a patient with Bell's palsy is corticosteroid therapy. Early administration within 72 hours of symptom onset greatly enhances the likelihood of complete recovery. Antivirals may be added in severe cases, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents at 18 weeks with low risk of trisomy on quadruple marker and high risk of NTD. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anomaly scan

 

The correct answer is Anomaly scan. This patient has a low risk of trisomy (such as Down syndrome) but a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) based on the quadruple marker test. The quadruple marker test includes measurements of beta-hCG, unconjugated estriol, inhibin A, and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). A high level of AFP is associated with an increased risk of NTDs, such as spina bifida.

 

Given the elevated risk for NTDs, the most appropriate next step is an anomaly scan, specifically a targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFA) scan. This ultrasound, typically performed between 18 and 20 weeks of gestation, has a high sensitivity (up to 99%) for detecting structural anomalies, particularly neural tube defects. The scan is a non-invasive way to assess the fetus for physical defects.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: While amniocentesis can detect chromosomal abnormalities and some structural defects, it is invasive and carries a small risk of complications. Since the concern here is structural (NTD) rather than chromosomal, and the anomaly scan is highly effective and non-invasive, amniocentesis is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): CVS is another invasive procedure used for early genetic testing, usually performed in the first trimester. It is not useful at 18 weeks and is not the best test for detecting structural anomalies like NTDs.

 

Option D. NIPT (Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing): NIPT is a screening tool for chromosomal aneuploidies (like trisomy 21, 18, and 13). Since the patient already has a low risk of trisomy, NIPT is unnecessary and does not address the high risk of NTD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a high risk of neural tube defects identified by elevated alpha-fetoprotein on a quadruple marker test, the best next step is an anomaly scan (TIFA), which is highly effective in identifying structural fetal abnormalities, including NTDs

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction limitation

 

This is not a feature of third nerve palsy. Abduction of the eye is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve. Limitation in abduction is indicative of sixth nerve palsy, not third nerve palsy. In third nerve palsy, there would be a limitation of adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose) instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) presents with several characteristic features due to the loss of function of the muscles it innervates:

 

Option A. Pupil dilatation: The third cranial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction. Damage to this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic stimulation, leading to pupil dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option B. Ptosis: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, responsible for elevating the eyelid, is innervated by the third cranial nerve. Damage to this nerve causes ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option C. Down and out eye: The unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the sixth cranial nerve) and the superior oblique (innervated by the fourth cranial nerve) results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the affected eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third nerve palsy presents with pupil dilatation, ptosis, and a down and out eye. Abduction limitation is not a feature of third nerve palsy; it is seen in sixth nerve palsy.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 → A, 2 → C, 3 → B, 4 → D

 

The matching of disorders with their respective clinical features or lab findings is based on the specific enzymatic defects associated with each type of glycogen storage disease (GSD).

 

  1. Cori’s Disease (Type III GSD):
    • Correct Match: A. Branched structure in liver biopsy
    • In Cori’s disease, the deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, often referred to as "limit dextrin." This structural abnormality can be observed in a liver biopsy.
       
  2. McArdle’s Disease (Type V GSD):
    • Correct Match: C. Exercise intolerance
    • McArdle’s disease is caused by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase (myophosphorylase), which is required for glycogen breakdown in muscle tissue. As a result, individuals with McArdle’s disease experience exercise intolerance due to the inability to produce adequate energy during physical activity.
       
  3. Pompe’s Disease (Type II GSD):
    • Correct Match: B. Accumulation of glycogen in lysosome
    • Pompe’s disease is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (alpha-glucosidase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes. This condition is also classified as a lysosomal storage disease.
       
  4. Von Gierke’s Disease (Type I GSD):
    • Correct Match: D. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
    • Von Gierke’s disease results from a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, an enzyme critical for gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. The lack of this enzyme leads to severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen storage diseases (GSDs) are classified based on the specific enzyme deficiency involved, leading to distinct clinical features such as exercise intolerance in McArdle’s disease, glycogen accumulation in lysosomes in Pompe’s disease, and hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis in Von Gierke’s disease.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are criteria for anaphylaxis? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Persistent abdominal cramps and vomiting
  2. Hypertension
  3. Urticaria and swollen lips
  4. Respiratory distress
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, c & d

 

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and requires immediate medical attention. The diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis typically involve the acute onset of symptoms affecting multiple organ systems.

 

a. Persistent abdominal cramps and vomiting: These are gastrointestinal symptoms that can be part of anaphylaxis when present with other criteria.

 

c. Urticaria and swollen lips: These are common skin manifestations of anaphylaxis.

 

d. Respiratory distress: Respiratory compromise is a key feature of anaphylaxis.

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Anaphylaxis (Acute onset – within minutes to hours)

 

Involvement of the skin, mucosal tissue + ≥ 1 of the following:

a. Respiratory compromise (e.g., dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, hypoxemia)

b. Hypotension or associated symptoms

 

≥ 2 of the following:

a. Involvement of the skin mucosal tissue

b. Respiratory compromise

c. Hypotension or associated symptoms

d. Persistent GI symptoms

 

Reduced BP after exposure to known allergen:

A. Infants and children – Low SBP (adjusted to age) or > 30% decrease in SBP

B. Adults – SBP < 90 mmHg or > 30% decrease in SBP

 

Other Option:

 

Option b. Hypertension: Anaphylaxis is typically associated with hypotension, not hypertension. Hypotension is a significant marker for the severity of the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylaxis is a severe allergic reaction that involves multiple organ systems and is characterized by symptoms such as urticaria, swollen lips, respiratory distress, and persistent gastrointestinal symptoms. Hypotension, rather than hypertension, is a critical diagnostic feature. Recognizing these criteria promptly is crucial for the immediate management of anaphylaxis.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahr’s triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient suffers with Intracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemiarthroplasty

 

INTRACAPSULAR FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE

 

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures (FNFs) account for approximately 50% of all hip fractures.
  • Intracapsular fractures demonstrate limited healing potential due to the absence of the periosteal layer, so the fracture is only immersed in the surrounding synovial fluid. 
  • These injuries occur secondary to low-energy falls in older individuals and higher-energy traumatic mechanisms in younger patients. 
  • However, most of these fractures occur in older people with underlying osteoporosis.
  • Displaced intracapsular femoral neck fractures in older people are typically managed with hip reconstruction procedures – the femoral head and neck are replaced with a reconstruction prosthesis.
  • These procedures include hip hemiarthroplasty or total hip arthroplasty (THA).
  • Non-displaced fractures may be managed with fixation using cannulated screw fixation.
  • Hemiarthroplasty, or femoral head replacement, is recommended for displaced intracapsular FNFs, especially in older patients with low activity levels.
  • THA is preferred for patients with intact ambulatory function or evidence of hip pain and degenerative arthritis.
  • Girdlestone resection arthroplasty (GRA) may be an option for patients who are unsuitable for hemiarthroplasty due to conditions like systemic infections or severe neurological impairment.
  • Hemiarthroplasty and THA are contraindicated in patients with an active hip infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Russell’s traction: This is a non-surgical method used for younger patients with femoral neck fracture with good bone quality. It might not be ideal for an 80-year-old due to potential complications from prolonged immobilization.

 

Option B. Bar and boot plaster: This non-surgical method also has limitations for elderly patients due to healing complications.

 

Option C. Intramedullary nailing: This surgical procedure uses nails to fix the fracture. While it can be an option, it might be risky for an 80-year-old's bone quality.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hemiarthroplasty is a surgical procedure where the damaged femoral head is replaced with an artificial joint, preserving the patient's own socket.
  • This offers a good balance between pain relief, mobility, and surgical complexity for elderly patients with this type of fracture.
  • The most appropriate management option for an 80-year-old patient with an intracapsular femoral neck fracture is Hemiarthroplasty.

choices.text: Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv
CT is the initial investigation for gallstones

questions.text: Identify the correct statement: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HU of water is zero

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) is a measure of radiodensity used in computed tomography (CT) scanning. By definition, the HU of water is zero, and this value serves as the reference point for measuring the density of other tissues. Values greater than zero indicate substances denser than water (e.g., bone, contrast material), while values less than zero indicate less dense substances (e.g., fat, air).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT uses non-filtered X-rays: This statement is incorrect. CT scans use filtered X-rays to remove low-energy X-rays that would not contribute to image formation but would increase patient radiation exposure.

 

Option B. Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv: This is incorrect. Typical radiation doses for CT scans vary based on the body part being imaged. A head CT scan, for instance, typically involves a radiation dose of around 2 mSv, while an abdominal CT scan might be around 5 mSv. A dose of 20 mSv would be exceedingly high for a single CT scan.

 

Option C. CT is the initial investigation for gallstones: This is incorrect. Ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice for gallstones due to its high sensitivity, specificity, and lack of ionizing radiation. CT is more commonly used for other types of stones, such as kidney stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) of water is zero, serving as a reference point for measuring the radiodensity of various tissues in CT imaging.

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

The histological image shows a lot of pink areas, indicative of necrosis, and an inflammatory infiltrate. These features are suggestive of caseous necrosis, surrounded by a ring of lymphocytes, which is characteristic of tuberculosis. Tuberculosis often affects the cervical lymph nodes, leading to their enlargement and caseous necrosis, commonly referred to as "matting" of the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: Incorrect. Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas and commonly affects the lungs and hilar lymph nodes, not typically the cervical lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Incorrect. This condition would show Langerhans cells (which have a characteristic appearance) and is not associated with the caseous necrosis seen in the image.

 

Option D. Hodgkin lymphoma: Incorrect. Hodgkin lymphoma presents with Reed Sternberg cells and does not show caseous necrosis. Although Hodgkin lymphoma can cause cervical lymph node enlargement, it does not fit the granulomatous inflammation pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

 

Histological Hallmarks of TB in Lymph Nodes:

 

  • Caseating granulomas (granulomas with central necrosis)
  • Surrounding epithelioid histiocytes, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes
  • Necrosis is a key differentiator from sarcoidosis (which has non-caseating granulomas)

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

questions.text: What is the stage of sleep denoted by the arrow: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

Explanation:

 

The stage of sleep indicated by the arrow is REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This can be identified based on the specific patterns observed in the EEG (Electroencephalogram), EMG (Electromyogram), and EOG (Electrooculogram) readings:

 

 

 

  • EEG: The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves.
  • EMG: The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams.
  • EOG: The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.

 

In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep stages (including NREM 2, 3, and 4) show different patterns:

 

  • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns.
  • Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep.
  • Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NREM 2: This stage of sleep is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG, with reduced but not absent muscle tone and minimal eye movement. The patterns described in the question do not match this stage.

 

Option B. NREM 3: Known as slow-wave sleep or deep sleep, NREM 3 is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. Muscle tone is decreased but not completely absent, and there is minimal to no eye movement. The pattern described does not correspond to NREM 3.

 

Option C. NREM 4: Often combined with NREM 3 in the modern classification, this stage is also characterized by delta waves, reduced muscle tone, and lack of eye movement. The described pattern is inconsistent with this stage as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, high-frequency EEG waves, muscle atonia as shown in the EMG, and rapid eye movements as shown in the EOG. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for correctly identifying REM sleep, which is a critical stage for processes like memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

choices.text: IgM is the most common antibody in ABO
ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth
ABO antigens are carbohydrates
Antibodies are present only if antigens are absent

questions.text: Regarding ABO blood grouping, which statement is false? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth

 

The statement "ABO antibodies are natural and present since birth" is false. While ABO antibodies are indeed considered natural antibodies, they are not present at birth. These antibodies develop through a process called molecular mimicry after exposure to gut commensals. Typically, ABO antibodies begin to appear around 3 to 6 months of age, not immediately after birth as the statement suggests.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. IgM is the most common antibody in ABO: This statement is correct. IgM is the predominant antibody type in the ABO blood group system. This characteristic is important because IgM antibodies, due to their large size, cannot cross the placenta, which is crucial for preventing complications during pregnancy.

 

Option C. ABO antigens are carbohydrates:  This statement is correct. ABO antigens are oligosaccharides, which are carbohydrate structures. This fact has been established and discussed multiple times in the context of blood group antigens.

 

Option D. Antibodies are present only if antigens are absent: This statement is also correct. In the ABO blood group system, an individual's blood will contain antibodies against the ABO antigens that are not present on their own red blood cells. This principle is fundamental to understanding ABO blood group compatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABO antibodies, while natural, are not present at birth but develop in the first few months of life (typically 3-6 months) through exposure to environmental factors, particularly gut bacteria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the goal is to prevent lactation to avoid discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. The appropriate treatment involves using a drug that can suppress prolactin secretion, as prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively suppressing lactation. It is often used for this purpose and can be an effective choice in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a direct role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can increase prolactin levels, which would not be helpful in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and antiemetic that also increases prolactin levels, making it unsuitable for suppressing lactation.

 

Given these options, the correct choice for preventing lactation and thus avoiding the associated complications is: b. Cabergoline

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy. This condition is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the tissues around the eyes, leading to inflammation and swelling. This results in the characteristic bulging of the eyes, known as proptosis or exophthalmos.

 

Thyroid eye disease is particularly common in middle-aged individuals and can cause both unilateral (one eye) and bilateral (both eyes) proptosis. The pathophysiology involves the expansion of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, leading to the protrusion of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tissue tumour in orbit: While soft tissue tumors in the orbit can cause proptosis, they are not the most common cause in middle-aged individuals. These tumors can be benign or malignant and require imaging studies for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Optic nerve meningioma: This type of tumor is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and can lead to proptosis. However, it is less common compared to thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Although cavernous hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in adults, it is not the most common cause of proptosis. These benign vascular tumors can cause proptosis if they become large enough to displace the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

choices.text: Enoxaparin
Lepirudin
Fondaparinux
Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulant requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that typically requires regular monitoring of anticoagulant effect via activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).
  • Enoxaparin (a low molecular weight heparin), Fondaparinux (a synthetic pentasaccharide), and Dabigatran (a direct thrombin inhibitor) generally do not require regular monitoring in most patients, although there may be specific clinical situations where monitoring is needed.

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Introjection

 

Introjection is a psychological process where a person unconsciously adopts the ideas or attributes of other people or objects. This is often discussed in psychoanalytic contexts, not cognitive ones.

 

It involves internalizing aspects of others, such as a child internalizing aspects of a lost parent, leading to complex emotional outcomes, which might contribute to the development of depressive feelings.

 

Other Options:

 

Beck's cognitive theory of depression posits that negative thoughts, cognitive distortions, and dysfunctional beliefs are central to the development and maintenance of depression.

 

Option A. Dysfunctional beliefs are ingrained, maladaptive beliefs developed over time, often from childhood experiences, that can trigger depression when activated by stress.

 

Option B. Cognitive distortions are systematic errors in thinking, such as all-or-nothing thinking or overgeneralization, which negatively influence one's perception of reality.

 

Option D. Automatic negative thoughts are recurring negative thoughts that occur spontaneously and contribute to the persistence of depressive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression; it is associated with psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on internalized feelings towards an object, such as a parent, and is less commonly used in contemporary understanding of depression.

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

NUTRITIONAL RICKETS

 

  • In nutritional rickets, the calcium to creatinine ratio in urine is generally low instead of high. 

  • This occurs because rickets is the result of a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, resulting in inadequate mineralization of bone. 

  • In reaction to conserve calcium levels, the body elevates the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the kidneys actively reabsorb calcium, resulting in low urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate. 

  • Thus, the ratio of calcium to creatinine in urine is not elevated in nutritional rickets, reflecting calcium conservation.

  • A high urine calcium to creatinine ratio would suggest hypercalciuria, which is characteristic of conditions like hyperparathyroidismwithout underlying vitamin D deficiency, or certain renal tubular disorders, but not nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: In nutritional rickets, vitamin D deficiency initially leads to decreased calcium absorption and a tendency for low serum calcium. This activates the compensatory mechanism of the body. The drop in serum calcium stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH then acts to increase calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and mobilizes calcium from the bones (resorption). This helps to maintain serum calcium levels within the normal range, at the expense of bone health. So, it is common to see normal serum calcium in many cases of nutritional rickets.

 

Option B. Elevated Parathyroid Hormone: In rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are frequently increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism) as the body attempts to counteract low calcium levels by enhancing calcium resorption from bones and kidneys. This is a hallmark of nutritional rickets and is the body's attempt to maintain calcium homeostasis.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: A key feature of nutritional rickets is decreased serum phosphorus resulting from compromised renal phosphate reabsorption, exacerbated by a deficiency of vitamin D. High levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) have a significant effect on phosphate metabolism. PTH causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate in the urine. This leads to hypophosphatemia, which directly impairs the mineralization of new bone and cartilage, leading to the characteristic bone deformities of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.

  • A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.

  • However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.

  • Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.
