Option C. Follicular cells: Incorrect. Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid cancers, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Hurthle cells: Incorrect. Hurthle cells are a variant of follicular cells and can be seen in Hurthle cell carcinoma, another type of thyroid cancer, but not in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma, characterized by nests of cells and amyloid deposition, arises from the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

 

Parvovirus B19 is known to cause several conditions, including erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash in children. It can also affect red blood cells, leading to pure red cell aplasia and aplastic crisis, especially in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders. In pregnant women, parvovirus B19 infection can cause hydrops fetalis, a serious condition characterized by severe fetal anemia and fluid accumulation. However, petechial rash is not typically associated with parvovirus B19 infection. Petechial rashes are more commonly linked to other viral infections or conditions that cause thrombocytopenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure red cell aplasia: Parvovirus B19 can infect erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems or underlying hematologic disorders.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia, making this a well-documented complication.

 

Option C. Aplastic crisis: In individuals with chronic hemolytic anemias, such as sickle cell disease, parvovirus B19 infection can precipitate an aplastic crisis by temporarily halting red blood cell production in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

questions.text: A 47-year-old renal transplant patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oval cysts 30 x 15 microns as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the causative organism:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isospora

 

In this case, the patient is a renal transplant recipient, indicating an immunocompromised state due to immunosuppressive drugs. Immunocompromised patients are more susceptible to infections, including parasitic infections causing diarrhea.

 

The stool examination revealed oval cysts measuring 30 x 15 microns, which were acid-fast positive. These characteristics are crucial in identifying the parasite:

 

  1. Immunocompromised State: This condition makes the patient more prone to infections by opportunistic parasites.
  2. Acid-Fast Positive Cysts: This staining characteristic is seen in certain parasitic cysts.
  3. Size and Shape of Cysts: The cysts are oval and measure 30 x 15 microns.

 

Based on the provided images and reference notes, Isospora belli (now known as Cystoisospora belli) is the parasite that fits these criteria. Isospora cysts are known to be oval in shape and measure approximately 20 to 30 microns in length, consistent with the 30 x 15 microns cysts described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium cysts are round, not oval, and are much smaller (4 to 6 microns). They do not fit the size and shape described in this case.

 

Option C. Cyclospora: Cyclospora cysts are also round and measure approximately 8 to 10 microns, which do not match the size and shape given in the question.

 

Option D. Microsporidia: Microsporidia produce very small spores (1 to 2 microns) and are not typically described as having 30 x 15 microns cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isospora belli (Cystoisospora belli) causes watery diarrhea in immunocompromised patients and is identified by its oval cysts measuring approximately 20 to 30 microns, which are acid-fast positive.

choices.text: Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.text: Identify the correct match out of the following diuretics and the respective site of action: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule

 

Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors: These diuretics inhibit the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, which is located predominantly in the proximal convoluted tubule. This inhibition reduces the reabsorption of bicarbonate, sodium, and water in this segment, making "Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule" the correct match.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics: These have a diffuse mechanism of action throughout the nephron, primarily affecting water-permeable regions such as the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle. The statement "Osmotic diuretics → Collecting duct" is incorrect as the major sites of action are the proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb, not just the collecting duct.

 

Option C. Thiazides: Thiazide diuretics act on the distal convoluted tubule by inhibiting the sodium-chloride transporter. They do not primarily act on the Loop of Henle, making "Thiazides → Loop of Henle" incorrect.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists: These drugs act on the collecting ducts, particularly affecting the principal cells where aldosterone promotes sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion. Therefore, the statement "Aldosterone antagonists → Distal Convoluted tubule" is incorrect as their primary site of action is the collecting duct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diuretics with their site of action:

 

  • Osmotic diuretics → Proximal convoluted tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle
  • Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitors → Proximal convoluted tubule
  • Thiazides → Distal convoluted tubule
  • Aldosterone antagonists → Collecting duct

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.

 

The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

choices.text: It should not be given with pyrazinamide
It should be taken empty stomach
It is given as a loading dose

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is being treated with voriconazole. He has been on the medication for two weeks and comes to the clinic for a follow-up. During the visit, he asks about the specific guidelines and considerations for taking voriconazole to ensure its effectiveness and safety. Which of the following statements is true about voriconazole? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is given as a loading dose
 

Voriconazole requires a loading dose to rapidly achieve therapeutic levels in the body. This is a crucial aspect of its administration, especially in acute settings where rapid antifungal activity is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with pyrazinamide: There is no significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole does interact with many other medications due to its effect on cytochrome P450 enzymes, but pyrazinamide is not one of the primary concerns.

 

Option B. It should be taken empty stomach: Voriconazole can be taken either with or without food, but it is generally recommended to take it one hour before or one hour after a meal to ensure optimal absorption. While this is important, it is not the most critical consideration compared to therapeutic drug monitoring.

 

Option D. It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: While therapeutic drug monitoring can be important for voriconazole, especially in certain patient populations, it is not as universally mandated or emphasized as the initial loading dose regimen in standard treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the statement that voriconazole "is given as a loading dose" is the most universally applicable and critical aspect of its administration, especially for ensuring rapid therapeutic levels in treating fungal infections.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) JNA

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males. The typical presentation includes nasal obstruction and recurrent episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds).

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic Rhinitis: Nasal obstruction but no recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Coagulation Disorder: Bleeding from multiple sites, not specific to nasal obstruction in adolescent males.

 

Option D. Antrochoanal Polyp: Nasal obstruction without recurrent epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, as it commonly presents in adolescent males with these symptoms.

choices.text: Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA)
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)
Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, and tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)

 

The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a condition commonly seen in diabetes patients with high blood sugar levels (RBS: 450 mg/dL). The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are characteristic of DKA.

 

The laboratory values indicate a metabolic acidosis:

 

  • pH of 7.34: Slightly acidic, indicating acidosis.
  • Bicarbonate of 12 mmol/L: Low, consistent with metabolic acidosis.
  • Chloride of 92 mmol/L: Lower than normal.

 

To determine the type of metabolic acidosis, we calculate the anion gap:

 

 

An anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L indicates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). In this case, the anion gap is 31, confirming HAGMA. 

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is typically associated with conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, renal failure, and ingestion of toxins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA): This occurs when the anion gap is normal (less than 12 mmol/L). Conditions that cause NAGMA include diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis. This does not match the patient's high anion gap.

 

Option C. Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis: This condition involves an elevated pH with high bicarbonate levels. The patient’s pH is acidic, not alkalotic, and bicarbonate is low.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Characterized by a primary increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels leading to a low pH. The patient’s primary disturbance is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by an anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L, indicating an accumulation of unmeasured anions. This condition is often seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, which presents with elevated blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis.

choices.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This procedure is primarily used to treat chronic adenoiditis and otitis media with effusion (OME), which are associated with conductive hearing loss (CHL), not SNHL. Since the child has SNHL, this treatment is not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) indicates that there is a problem in the inner ear (cochlea) or the auditory nerve. When treating bilateral SNHL in a child, certain interventions are preferred based on the underlying pathology and the severity of the hearing loss.

 

Option A. Cochlear Implant: This is a viable option for children with severe to profound SNHL where the cochlea is affected but the auditory nerve is intact. The implant bypasses the damaged cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear.

 

Option C. Making him sit in front row in class: This is a common accommodation to help children with hearing loss to better hear and engage in classroom activities. It minimizes the distance between the child and the teacher, thus reducing the impact of hearing loss.

 

Option D.  Hearing Aid: This is suitable for children with mild to moderate SNHL. Hearing aids amplify sounds, making them louder and easier to hear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

  • Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors available on the surface of liver cells, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. It is used for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that works by reducing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. It is used to lower LDL cholesterol levels but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3), which reduces levels of triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, and other lipids. It is used for treating homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor used primarily as an immunosuppressant in transplant patients and in certain types of cancer. It is not related to cholesterol metabolism and is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text:
Which of these are the components of high-quality CPR? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a) Compression rate 100-120/min

b) Depth of compression in adults is 3-4 cm

c) Ventilation of 2 breaths for every 30 compressions

d) Allow complete chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, c & d

 

High-quality CPR in adults requires several critical components to be effective. These include:

 

a. Compression Rate: The compression rate should be between 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate is optimal to maintain blood flow during cardiac arrest.

 

b. Depth of Compression: For adults, the correct depth of compression is at least 2 inches (approximately 5 cm). The depth mentioned in the option B (3-4 cm) is incorrect as it is insufficient to generate adequate blood flow.

 

c. Ventilation: The recommended ventilation ratio is 2 breaths for every 30 compressions if no advanced airway is in place. This ensures adequate oxygenation during CPR.

 

d. Chest Recoil: Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression is essential. This allows the heart to refill with blood between compressions, which is crucial for effective circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For high-quality CPR in adults, ensure a compression rate of 100-120/min, a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm), a ventilation ratio of 30:2, and allow complete chest recoil between compressions.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. A Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells. The mother has a history of genital lesions. What is the likely diagnosis, and what is the causative agent? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HSV 2

 

In this scenario, the 18-month-old baby presents with vesicles on the anterior abdominal wall and forearm, as well as meningitis. The Tzanck smear shows multinucleate giant cells, which are indicative of a herpes virus infection. Given the mother’s history of genital lesions, it is highly suggestive that the baby contracted the infection during delivery.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Vesicles: The presence of vesicles (fluid-filled blisters) is characteristic of herpes infections.
  • Tzanck Smear: This test shows multinucleate giant cells, which are typical findings in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections.
  • Mother's Genital Lesions: This detail strongly indicates genital herpes, which is most commonly caused by HSV-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella Zoster: Although varicella zoster virus (VZV) can cause vesicles and multinucleate giant cells, the history of maternal genital lesions and the clinical presentation points more specifically towards HSV.

 

Option C. Enterococcus: This bacterium is not associated with vesicular lesions or multinucleate giant cells on Tzanck smear. It typically causes urinary tract infections, bacteremia, and endocarditis, not the described symptoms.

 

Option D. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis can cause congenital infections but does not present with vesicular skin lesions or multinucleate giant cells. The typical findings include intracranial calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HSV-2 is a common cause of neonatal herpes, which presents with vesicular lesions and can be confirmed with a Tzanck smear showing multinucleate giant cells. Maternal genital herpes is a significant risk factor for neonatal transmission.

questions.text: A primigravida is in the 2nd stage of labor for 2 hours. The head is at +3 with caput present and the fetal heart rate (FHR) is dropping to 90 bpm. What is the best way to deliver the head? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Outlet forceps

 

In this scenario, the patient is a primigravida (a woman pregnant for the first time) who is in the second stage of labor, which has been ongoing for 2 hours. The second stage of labor in a primigravida can be allowed up to 3 hours if the mother and fetus are stable. However, in this case, the fetal heart rate has dropped to 90 bpm, indicating fetal distress, and the head is at +3 station, meaning it is very low in the pelvis, almost at the pelvic floor.

 

  • Outlet forceps are specifically designed for situations where the fetal head is at +3 station or lower. The head is visible at the introitus without separating the labia, and delivery needs to be expedited due to fetal distress. In this case, the application of outlet forceps is preferred because it allows for a quicker delivery compared to other methods. This is critical when there is evidence of fetal distress, as time is of the essence to reduce the risk of hypoxia.
  • Mid cavity forceps are used when the fetal head is higher in the pelvis, typically at 0 to +1 station. This option is not suitable in this case because the head is much lower, at +3 station.
  • Low forceps are used when the head is at +2 station, slightly higher than in this scenario. They are not appropriate when the head is at +3 station.
  • Ventouse (vacuum extraction) can be used at various stations, but it is generally slower to apply compared to forceps. Additionally, the presence of caput (swelling of the fetal scalp) can make it difficult to achieve the necessary suction for effective vacuum delivery. Therefore, outlet forceps are preferred in this scenario to ensure a quicker and more effective delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mid cavity forceps: Incorrect because they are used when the head is at a higher station, typically 0 to +1, and the head is not yet at the pelvic floor.

 

Option B. Low forceps: Incorrect because they are more suitable when the head is at +2 station, not when it is already at +3 station.

 

Option D. Ventouse (vacuum extraction): While it could technically be used, it is not the best choice here because of the fetal distress and the presence of caput, which may hinder the effective application of the vacuum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of fetal distress with the fetal head at +3 station, outlet forceps are the preferred method of assisted delivery due to their speed and effectiveness, particularly when caput is present.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children can present as either Kwashiorkor or Marasmus. These conditions cause the child to appear very thin and emaciated, making it challenging to rely on typical physical signs like skin pinch or sunken eyeballs for dehydration assessment. SAM children, especially those with Marasmus, already have a "baggy pant" appearance and very thin skin, making these signs unreliable.

 

The most reliable indicator of dehydration in SAM children is assessing urine output, thirst and the condition of the oral mucosa:

 

  • ⁠Urine output, thirst: If the child eagerly drinks water, it indicates some dehydration. Refusal to drink or feed may suggest severe dehydration.
  • ⁠Oral mucosa: Checking the dryness of the oral mucosa is a practical and reliable method. In SAM children, if the oral mucosa is dry, it indicates dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin pinch: This option is incorrect because SAM children already have very thin skin, making skin pinch an unreliable indicator.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: This option is incorrect as SAM children naturally have sunken eyeballs due to severe weight loss and malnutrition, making this sign unreliable for detecting dehydration.

 

Option D. Absent tears: this indicator is not the best indicator. It can be seen in some as well as severe dehydration cases. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient suffers with extracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intramedullary nailing

 

INTRAMEDULLARY NAILING

 

  • Intramedullary Nailing is a surgical technique used to stabilize fractures by inserting a metal rod (nail) into the medullary canal of the bone.
  • Mechanism: The nail is inserted into the central canal of the femur and fixed with screws at the ends to stabilize the fracture.

 

 

  • It is generally used for femoral shaft fractures but can be applied to extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly.
  • Indications: Intramedullary nailing is effective for stabilizing long bone fractures and can be used for femoral neck fractures if the fracture pattern and bone quality are suitable.
  • Complications: There is a risk of complications including infection, nonunion, and poor functional outcomes if not done properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Russell’s Traction: Russell’s Traction is a type of skeletal traction used to align and stabilize fractures, particularly in the lower extremities. This traction method involves applying a pulling force to the limb through a system of pulleys and weights. It can help in aligning fractured bones and reducing pain by immobilizing the affected limb. For elderly patients with extracapsular femoral neck fractures, Russell’s traction is less preferred due to delayed recovery as the traction does not allow early weight-bearing or mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to prevent complications like pressure sores and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The immobilization provided by traction alone might not adequately stabilize the fracture, leading to a higher risk of nonunion or malunion. Prolonged use of traction can lead to muscle atrophy and joint stiffness.

 

 

Option B. Bar and Boot Plaster: Bar and Boot Plaster is a type of external immobilization used for fractures, particularly in the lower limb. This involves applying a plaster cast to immobilize the fractured limb, often including a bar and boot to provide additional support and alignment. It is used for fractures where conservative management is appropriate, particularly in pediatric or less complex cases. For extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients, this method is generally not preferred due to inadequate stabilization. Prolonged immobilization can lead to complications such as muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and pressure sores, especially in elderly patients who are already at high risk for these issues.

 

 

Option D. Hemiarthroplasty: Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the damaged femoral head with a prosthetic component while leaving the acetabulum intact. It is often used to address both the fracture and any pre-existing joint degeneration. Hemiarthroplasty is often preferred for intracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to immediate stability provided to the hip joint and allowance for earlier weight-bearing and mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to reduce the risk of complications from prolonged immobility. The prosthesis can alleviate pain and improve functional outcomes compared to conservative management methods. The procedure has risks such as dislocation, infection, and prosthesis failure, but it generally provides better outcomes in terms of mobility and quality of life for elderly patients compared to non-surgical methods.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing, while useful for certain types of fractures, is generally the first choice for extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to the risks and potential complications associated with the procedure.
  • Cephalomedullary nailing is done in such cases.

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

questions.text: Devices which are not used in colorimetric test? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

Explanation:

 

The tools shows is the Sahli's method for hemoglobin estimation, a type of colorimetric test.

 

RBC pipette: This device is specifically designed for counting red blood cells and is marked with a red bead. It is not used in hemoglobin estimation via the colorimetric method. The RBC pipette plays no role in this test, which is why it is the correct answer for the device that is not used in this process.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Comparator: This is used to compare the color intensity of the hemoglobin solution with standard color shades to estimate the hemoglobin concentration.

 

Option C. Hemoglobinometer tube: A crucial component of the Sahli's hemoglobinometer, this tube is marked for measuring hemoglobin concentration in percentage and grams per deciliter.

 

Option D. N/10 HCl: This reagent is used to convert hemoglobin into acid hematin, which can then be measured using the colorimetric method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not used in the Sahli's method of hemoglobin estimation, which employs a colorimetric test involving the hemoglobinometer tube, comparator, and N/10 HCl.

questions.text: Which contrast agent is safe in a patient with renal failure? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG contrast agents

 

Ultrasound (USG) contrast agents, specifically SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are safe to use in patients with renal failure. These microbubbles are filled with gas and are excreted via the lungs rather than the kidneys, making them suitable for patients with compromised renal function. Unlike other contrast agents, USG contrast agents do not rely on renal clearance, thereby avoiding the risk of further renal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI contrast agents (Gadolinium-based): These agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, a serious condition affecting the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Iodinated contrast: Commonly used in CT imaging, these agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, which can further impair renal function.

 

Option D. CT contrast agent: Typically, iodinated contrast is used in CT imaging, which is not safe for patients with renal failure for the reasons mentioned above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

USG contrast agents, such as SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are the only contrast agents safe for use in patients with renal failure as they are excreted via the lungs and do not rely on renal clearance.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure:(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior rib

 

The marked structure in the provided chest X-ray image points to the horizontal part of the rib, which is indicative of the posterior rib. In radiographic anatomy, the posterior ribs are visualized as horizontal structures on a chest X-ray, whereas the anterior ribs appear more curved as they wrap around the thoracic cavity. This distinction is crucial for identifying the ribs accurately.

 

The posterior ribs are highlighted because they are flatter and more horizontal compared to the anterior ribs, which curve forward.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior rib: The anterior ribs are more curved and not horizontal like the posterior ribs. The marked structure clearly shows a horizontal rib, which excludes the anterior rib as the correct answer.

 

Option C. Costal cartilage: Costal cartilage does not show up on standard X-rays because it is not as radiopaque as bone. Therefore, it cannot be the marked structure.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery: The pulmonary artery would appear in the lung hilum and would not resemble the horizontal rib structure. Thus, it is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior rib appears as a horizontal structure on a chest X-ray, distinguishing it from the more curved anterior ribs and other thoracic structures.

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulointerstitial nephritis

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis, also known as acute allergic interstitial nephritis, is often caused by an allergic reaction to medications such as antibiotics. In this scenario, the patient had a fever and sore throat and was subsequently treated with antibiotics, likely from the penicillin group. Penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics are common culprits in causing type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, leading to the presence of eosinophils in the urine (eosinophiluria). This condition is also associated with the presence of WBC casts in the urine, indicating inflammation of the renal interstitium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This condition typically presents with RBC casts rather than WBC casts and does not involve eosinophiluria. It follows a streptococcal infection and involves immune complex deposition in the glomeruli.

 

Option C. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to glomerulonephritis. It is not typically associated with eosinophiluria and primarily presents with RBC casts.

 

Option D. Rhabdomyolysis: Rhabdomyolysis involves the breakdown of muscle tissue, leading to the release of muscle contents into the bloodstream, including myoglobin, which can cause renal damage. It is characterized by elevated creatine kinase levels and does not present with eosinophiluria or WBC casts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

choices.text: Chronic Cocaine use
Subacute progression over 4 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of underlying serious pathology in headache? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Cocaine use

 

While acute cocaine use can lead to serious complications such as intracranial hemorrhage, chronic cocaine use does not typically present as a headache warning sign for serious pathology unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age > 50: New onset headache in individuals over 50 years of age is a red flag and suggests the possibility of serious conditions such as giant cell arteritis or intracranial mass lesions.

 

Option B. Temporal tenderness: This is often a sign of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis), a serious condition that can lead to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Subacute progression over 4 weeks: This indicates a progressive condition such as a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, which are serious pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder

 

  • Sudden-onset headache
  • First severe headache
  • "Worst" headache ever
  • Vomiting that precedes headache
  • Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • Known systemic illness
  • Onset after age 55
  • Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • Abnormal neurologic examination
  • Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

choices.text: Intact cell organelle
Altered cell shape
Enzyme mediated degradation
Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered cell shape

 

Necrosis and apoptosis are two distinct types of cell death, each with its own characteristics.

 

Altered cell shape: While cell shape can change in both necrosis and apoptosis, it is not a reliable indicator to differentiate between the two. The more useful parameter is cell size: in necrosis, cells swell, whereas in apoptosis, cells shrink. Therefore, altered cell shape is not particularly helpful in distinguishing necrosis from apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intact cell organelle: During apoptosis, cell organelles remain intact until the late stages when apoptotic bodies form. These bodies contain tightly packed cytoplasmic components and organelles. In contrast, necrosis is characterized by the breakdown and disintegration of organelles. Thus, the presence of intact organelles helps differentiate apoptosis from necrosis.

 

Option C. Enzyme mediated degradation: This is a hallmark of necrosis. In necrosis, enzymes digest cellular components, leading to the breakdown of organelles and other structures. This feature is not seen in apoptosis, where cellular components are typically preserved until the cell is packaged into apoptotic bodies.

 

Option D. Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change: Necrosis involves the disintegration of organelles and changes in lipids, leading to the loss of cell membrane integrity. This is not a feature of apoptosis, where the membrane remains intact until late stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: Crohn’s disease in comparison to ulcerative colitis is least likely to show which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continuous involvement of the gut

 

Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), but they have distinct pathological and clinical features.

 

Key Features of Crohn's Disease:

 

  • Segmental involvement: Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, segmental involvement of the gastrointestinal tract, known as "skip lesions." This contrasts with ulcerative colitis, which typically involves continuous, uninterrupted inflammation of the colon.

 

Continuous Involvement of the Gut:

 

This feature is typical of ulcerative colitis, where the inflammation is continuous and starts from the rectum extending proximally in a continuous manner without skipping any areas. In Crohn's disease, the inflammation is discontinuous, with normal areas interspersed between inflamed regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced risk of colon cancer: This is true for Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, as the risk of progression to malignancy is generally lower, especially for non-colonic Crohn's.

 

Option C. Higher risk of perianal fistula: Crohn's disease has a higher risk of perianal complications, including fistulas, due to the transmural nature of its inflammation.

 

Option D. Rarely present with daily hematochezia: Daily hematochezia is less common in Crohn's disease compared to ulcerative colitis, which is more likely to cause continuous bloody diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Continuous involvement of the gut is least likely to be associated with Crohn's disease, which is characterized by segmental, patchy inflammation known as "skip lesions."

 

Key Differences Between Crohn’s Disease & Ulcerative Colitis:

questions.text:
What is the antidote of cyanide poisoning? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

A. Amyl Nitrite
B. Sodium Nitrite
C. Sodium Thiosulphate
D. Benzyl Thiocyanate
E. Sodium Nitroprusside
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABC

 

Cyanide poisoning inhibits cytochrome C oxidase, a key enzyme in the mitochondrial electron transport chain, leading to cellular hypoxia and lactic acidosis. The treatment for cyanide poisoning involves agents that either bind to cyanide, facilitating its excretion, or convert it into a less toxic form.

 

A. Amyl Nitrite and B. Sodium Nitrite: These compounds oxidize hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome C oxidase. This process frees cytochrome C oxidase and forms cyanmethemoglobin.

 

C. Sodium Thiosulphate: This compound acts directly by converting cyanmethemoglobin to thiocyanate, which is less toxic and is excreted in the urine. Additionally, it directly breaks the bond between cytochrome C oxidase and cyanide.

 

D. Benzyl Thiocyanate: This is not a recognized treatment for cyanide poisoning and does not have the properties needed to detoxify cyanide.

 

E. Sodium Nitroprusside: This compound, while containing cyanide groups, is not used as an antidote for cyanide poisoning. It is actually a source of cyanide and is used for different medical purposes, such as vasodilation in hypertensive emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main antidotes for cyanide poisoning include amyl nitrite, sodium nitrite, and sodium thiosulphate. These agents work by either converting cyanide into a less toxic form or by forming methemoglobin which binds to cyanide, freeing cytochrome C oxidase.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

 

During a fetal autopsy, the abdomen is typically examined before the thorax to assess the level of the diaphragm. The position of the diaphragm can indicate whether respiration has taken place. If the diaphragm is at the level of the 4th to 5th rib, it suggests that respiration has not occurred. If it is at the level of the 6th to 7th rib, it indicates that respiration has taken place. Although there is no strict rule about the order of examining the head, it is generally preferred to examine the head first to check for any hemorrhages. The correct sequence provided in the options is Head > Abdomen > Thorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thorax > Abdomen > Thorax: Incorrect. This option repeats the thorax examination and does not include the head, which is important for checking for hemorrhages.

 

Option B. Thorax > Head > Abdomen: Incorrect. The abdomen should be examined before the thorax to check the diaphragm level, which is crucial for determining whether respiration has occurred.

 

Option D. Head > Thorax > Abdomen: Incorrect. This option does not follow the necessary sequence where the abdomen should be examined before the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence

choices.text: Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction
Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night
Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart
Hypoxemia stimulates respiratory effort

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness, and his wife also complains that he snores a lot at night during sleep. Which of the following is incorrect regarding his condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction

 

The patient's symptoms suggest obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), a condition characterized by repeated episodes of partial or complete obstruction of the upper airway during sleep, leading to disrupted sleep and decreased oxygen levels.

 

 Increased tone of the pharyngeal muscles worsens obstruction: This statement is incorrect. In obstructive sleep apnea, the problem is actually due to the decreased tone or flaccidity of the pharyngeal muscles during sleep, which causes the airway to collapse and obstruct. Increased tone of these muscles would actually help keep the airway open.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fall of oxygen saturation triggers waking episodes at night: This statement is correct. During episodes of apnea, the blood oxygen levels drop, leading to hypoxemia. This triggers arousal from sleep to restore normal breathing, leading to fragmented sleep and excessive daytime sleepiness.

 

Option C. Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart: This statement is correct. The repetitive episodes of apnea and hypoxemia increase the work of breathing and intrathoracic pressure changes, which can increase stress on the heart, leading to potential cardiovascular complications such as hypertension and heart failure.

 

Option D. Hypoxemia stimulates respiratory effort: This statement is correct. Hypoxemia (low blood oxygen levels) and hypercapnia (high carbon dioxide levels) stimulate the brain's respiratory centers, increasing respiratory effort to overcome the obstruction and restore normal breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obstructive sleep apnea, decreased tone or flaccidity of the pharyngeal muscles during sleep leads to airway collapse and obstruction. Increased muscle tone would help keep the airway open and is not a cause of obstruction in this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following does not play a role in fetal growth?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth hormone

 

Growth hormone (GH) does not play a significant role in fetal growth. The primary regulators of fetal growth are insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) and thyroxine. IGFs are critical for cellular growth and differentiation during fetal development. Thyroxine, a thyroid hormone, is essential for brain development and overall growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factors: These play a crucial role in fetal growth by promoting cellular growth and differentiation.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: This hormone is vital for proper development, particularly for brain development and metabolic regulation.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because growth hormone does not significantly influence fetal growth, while IGFs and thyroxine do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, while insulin-like growth factors and thyroxine are crucial for proper fetal development.

choices.text: Increased formation of Heinz body
Males and females can be affected
Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about a patient with G6PD deficiency?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced oxidative stress inside the red cells

 

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects the red blood cells' ability to handle oxidative stress.

 

This is incorrect. G6PD deficiency actually increases oxidative stress inside red blood cells because the reduced NADPH levels lead to a decrease in reduced glutathione. This makes the cells more susceptible to oxidative damage.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increased formation of Heinz body: Correct because this is a hallmark of G6PD deficiency due to oxidative damage to hemoglobin.

 

Option B. Males and females can be affected: Correct; while males are more commonly affected, females can also be affected due to the X-linked inheritance pattern.

 

Option C. Reduced NADPH: Correct because this is a direct consequence of G6PD deficiency as the enzyme is essential for NADPH production in red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD deficiency increases oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis and formation of Heinz bodies. It affects both males and females, though more commonly males.

questions.text: Match the Dermatological disorders in Column A with their respective investigations in Column B: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

Correct matches:

 

 

1. Tinea: Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis, are fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails. The diagnosis is commonly made by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings, which reveals fungal hyphae under a microscope.

 

2. Lepromatous leprosy: This form of leprosy is diagnosed using a slit skin smear, where a sample from the skin lesion is stained and examined for the presence of acid-fast bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae).

 

 

3. Lupus vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. The diagnosis often involves a biopsy of the lesion, which shows granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis and the presence of acid-fast bacilli.

 

4. Allergic dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is diagnosed using a patch test, where suspected allergens are applied to the skin under occlusive patches to observe for a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea is diagnosed with a KOH mount, lepromatous leprosy with a slit skin smear, lupus vulgaris with a biopsy, and allergic dermatitis with a patch test.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not approved for treatment of (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rett syndrome

 

  • Cannabinoids, including cannabidiol (CBD), are not currently approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome. 
  • Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurological disorder, and while there is ongoing research into potential treatments, cannabinoids are not among the approved therapies for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy. It is used to reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: Cannabidiol (CBD) is also approved for the treatment of seizures associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). It has been shown to reduce seizure frequency in patients with TSC.

 

Option D. Lennox Gastaut syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, another severe form of epilepsy. It is used to help reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD), are not approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome, whereas they are approved for use in Dravet Syndrome, Tuberous Sclerosis, and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female suffers a proximal 1/3rd Femoral shaft fracture. What would be the ideal treatment option?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intramedullary nailing

 

FEMORAL SHAFT FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • Treatment of femoral shaft fractures can be operative or non-operative.
  • Operative fixation with intramedullary nailing is the gold standard treatment.
  • Other operative techniques include plate osteosynthesis and external fixation.
  • Closed treatment with traction, splinting, and casting may be temporary treatment.

 

Intramedullary Nailing

 

  • Intramedullary nailing (IMN) is the gold standard of treatment for femoral shaft fractures.
  • Early treatment in a stable patient within 24-48 hours reduces the incidence of pulmonary complications, infection, and mortality.
  • Delayed treatment increases pulmonary complications in up to 56% of patients compared to only 16% of patients treated early.
  • The insertion site of an IMN is outside the zone of injury, preserving the surrounding blood flow and retain the hematoma that contains beneficial bone growth factors.
  • It provides a strong and stable internal fixation that allows for early mobilization and weight-bearing, which is crucial for promoting healing and preventing complications.
  • It is a minimally invasive surgical procedure compared to other options like plate fixation, resulting in less tissue disruption and blood loss.
  • It helps in a faster recovery time and a quicker return to daily activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip Spica: This is a cast that extends from the waist to the toes and is not typically used for femoral shaft fractures due to the limited mobility it allows.

 

Option B. Above Knee Slab: An above-knee slab is a temporary cast that can be used for pain management and swelling reduction but doesn't provide enough stability for healing a fractured femoral shaft.

 

Option C. Above Knee Cast: Similar to an above-knee slab, a cast offers limited stability and wouldn't be suitable for the long-term treatment of this fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing is the treatment option of choice in proximal femoral shaft fractures as it is minimally invasive and provides faster recovery.

choices.text: Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile
Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in umbilical artery

questions.text: All are criteria of IUGR except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine A PI < 95%

 

Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR) is a condition where a fetus is smaller than expected for the number of weeks of pregnancy. It can result from various factors, including placental insufficiency, maternal health issues, or genetic conditions. Several criteria are commonly used to diagnose IUGR:

 

  • Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a common marker used in the assessment of IUGR. A small abdominal circumference indicates that the fetus might not be growing adequately.
  • Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: Like abdominal circumference, if the estimated fetal weight is below the 3rd percentile, it is a strong indicator of IUGR.
  • Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical finding on Doppler ultrasound that indicates severe placental insufficiency. It is associated with increased risk of adverse perinatal outcomes.

 

However, the option "Uterine A PI < 95%" refers to the uterine artery pulsatility index (PI), which is a measure of the resistance in the uterine artery. In cases of IUGR, resistance is typically high, leading to a high PI, not low. Therefore, a PI < 95% (indicating low resistance) would not be consistent with IUGR. This is why this option is incorrect.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Abdominal circumference < 3rd percentile: This is a valid criterion used in the assessment of IUGR.

 

Option B. Estimated fetal weight < 3rd percentile: This criterion is also used in the diagnosis of IUGR.

 

Option C. Absent or reversal of diastolic flow in the umbilical artery: This is a critical sign of severe IUGR and is often associated with poor perinatal outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is typically high in cases of IUGR due to increased resistance. A low PI (< 95%) would not indicate IUGR, making it the incorrect option in this contex

questions.text: Which of the following is an intranuclear immuno-histochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INSM

 

Intranuclear immunohistochemistry markers are specifically located within the nucleus of the cell, unlike cytoplasmic or membranous markers.

 

INSM (Insulinoma Associated Protein 1) is a novel intranuclear marker used for the detection of neuroendocrine tumors. It is particularly useful in diagnosing various types of neuroendocrine tumors, including small cell carcinoma of the lung, medullary thyroid cancer, Merkel cell carcinoma, and paraganglioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromogranin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option B. NCAM: Incorrect because it is a membranous marker, not intranuclear.

 

Option C. Synaptophysin: Incorrect because it is a cytoplasmic marker, not intranuclear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

INSM is an intranuclear marker for neuroendocrine tumors, distinguishing it from other cytoplasmic or membranous markers such as Chromogranin, NCAM, and Synaptophysin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amino acid-derived neurotransmitter? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Creatine

 

The question asks which of the listed options is not a neurotransmitter derived from amino acids. To answer this, let's break down each of the options:

 

  • Dopamine is a well-known neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is first converted to DOPA, which then converts to dopamine. Dopamine plays various roles in the brain, including involvement in reward, motivation, and the pathophysiology of schizophrenia.
  • Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) is derived from the amino acid tryptophan. Tryptophan is converted into 5-hydroxytryptophan, which is then decarboxylated to form serotonin. Serotonin is involved in mood regulation, sleep, and other functions.
  • GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an inhibitory neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate. The conversion of glutamate to GABA involves a decarboxylation reaction that requires vitamin B6 as a cofactor. GABA plays a crucial role in reducing neuronal excitability throughout the nervous system.
  • Creatine, however, is not a neurotransmitter. While creatine is synthesized from the amino acids glycine, arginine, and methionine, it functions primarily as a molecule that helps to supply energy to cells, particularly muscle cells, by regenerating ATP (adenosine triphosphate). Creatine is not involved in neurotransmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tyrosine.

 

Option B. Serotonin: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid tryptophan.

 

Option C. GABA: Incorrect, because it is a neurotransmitter derived from the amino acid glutamate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creatine is not a neurotransmitter. It is a molecule that plays a key role in energy metabolism, particularly in muscle cells, but it does not function in neurotransmission. Dopamine, serotonin, and GABA, on the other hand, are all neurotransmitters derived from amino acids.

choices.text: Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension
Obstructive Sleep Apnea

questions.text: Inhaled NO is used in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension

 

Inhaled nitric oxide (NO) is a potent pulmonary vasodilator used primarily in the management of various conditions associated with elevated pulmonary artery pressures. Its primary uses include:

 

  • Primary Pulmonary Artery Hypertension (A): Inhaled NO is used to reduce pulmonary artery pressures and right ventricular afterload in patients with primary pulmonary hypertension. It helps improve oxygenation and reduce symptoms associated with this condition.
  • Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Inhaled NO can be used to lower pulmonary pressures and relieve right ventricular strain.
  • Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH): Inhaled NO is used for vasoreactivity testing and to manage secondary forms of PAH.
  • Right Ventricular Failure in STEMI: Particularly in inferior STEMI with right ventricular myocardial infarction (RVMI), inhaled NO can reduce right ventricular afterload.
  • Refractory Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): Used as a bridging therapy to improve oxygenation until a more definitive treatment, such as lung transplantation, is available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive Sleep Apnea: This condition is typically managed with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy and lifestyle modifications.

 

Option C. Unstable Angina: Managed with anti-anginal medications, antiplatelet therapy, and revascularization procedures as needed.

 

Option D. Erectile Dysfunction: Treated with phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil), hormone therapy, or mechanical devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled nitric oxide is primarily used to manage conditions with elevated pulmonary artery pressures, such as primary pulmonary artery hypertension. It is not used for obstructive sleep apnea, unstable angina, or erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

 

Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, is indicated by a height for age that is significantly below the normal. According to World Health Organization (WHO) standards, a height for age that is less than minus 2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population is indicative of stunting. In this question, the child has a height for age of minus 2 SD, which points to chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: This is typically indicated by a significant weight loss over a short period, reflected in weight for height measurements. A weight for height less than minus 3 SD from the median would indicate severe acute malnutrition, but in this case, the weight for height is less than minus 1 SD, which is not sufficient to diagnose acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Acute on chronic malnutrition: This would be indicated if the child had signs of both chronic malnutrition (height for age less than minus 2 SD) and significant recent weight loss. However, the weight for height is only less than minus 1 SD, not indicative of acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as chronic malnutrition is clearly indicated by the height for age of minus 2 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

questions.text: Indicated structure gives origin to which of the following fiber (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dentato-rubral

 

The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is the largest and most lateral of these nuclei. It is involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers. These fibers project from the dentate nucleus to the red nucleus in the midbrain, playing a crucial role in the coordination of motor movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-rubral: Incorrect because while it involves the cerebellum and red nucleus, the correct specific term for the fiber originating from the dentate nucleus is "dentato-rubral."

 

Option B. Cerebello-reticul: Incorrect because this option refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the reticular formation, not specifically involving the dentate nucleus.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibul: Incorrect because this refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation, not related to the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers, which project to the red nucleus and are crucial for motor coordination.

choices.text: Syrup Dextromethorphan with bromhexine

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with fever, cough, and tenacious white sputum. Which of the following should be used for treatment? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syrup Bromhexine

 

The patient presents with a productive cough characterized by tenacious white sputum. In such cases, it is essential to use a treatment that helps break down and clear the mucus to prevent further complications like infections.

 

Syrup Bromhexine is a mucolytic agent that works by breaking down mucus, making it easier to clear from the respiratory tract. This is the most appropriate treatment for a patient with thick, tenacious sputum as it will help in liquefying the mucus and promoting its expulsion through coughing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syrup Dextromethorphan with bromhexine: This combination does not make sense therapeutically. Dextromethorphan is an antitussive, which suppresses cough, while bromhexine is a mucolytic, which helps break down mucus. Using them together is illogical because you do not want to suppress the cough when the patient has productive sputum that needs to be expelled.

 

Option B. Syrup Codeine: Codeine is also an antitussive and should not be used in patients with productive cough. Suppressing the cough can lead to accumulation of sputum, which can cause infections.

 

Option C. Syrup Dextromethorphan: Similar to codeine, dextromethorphan is an antitussive and is not appropriate for treating a productive cough. It will suppress the cough reflex, leading to retention of mucus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a productive cough and thick, tenacious sputum, mucolytic agents like bromhexine should be used to help break down and clear the mucus, rather than suppressing the cough reflex with antitussives.

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhaled anesthetic agent for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients. This is primarily due to its pleasant, sweet smell, which makes it more tolerable for children to inhale. Additionally, Sevoflurane has a rapid onset of action, meaning it works quickly to induce anesthesia. This quick induction is critical in pediatric patients who often do not have an intravenous (IV) line placed before induction. The ability to induce anesthesia effectively and without distress is a significant advantage in this age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is not preferred for pediatric induction because it has a pungent odor, which can be irritating and unpleasant for children. Moreover, it can cause airway irritation, which is undesirable during induction.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: While Isoflurane is effective as an anesthetic, it also has a pungent smell and slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential for causing liver toxicity and its slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:


Sevoflurane is the anesthetic agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its sweet smell and rapid onset of action.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with unexplained diarrhea? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metformin

 

  • Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. 
  • It is well known to cause gastrointestinal side effects, including diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, particularly when first starting the medication or when the dose is increased. 
  • Diarrhea is one of the most common side effects of metformin and can sometimes be severe or persistent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not commonly associated with diarrhea. Its common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option B. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analog used as an adjunct treatment for diabetes. It slows gastric emptying and promotes satiety but is not typically associated with diarrhea. Nausea is a more common gastrointestinal side effect.

 

Option C. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion from the pancreas. It is not known to cause diarrhea. Hypoglycemia is its most significant side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, metformin is the anti-diabetic drug most commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea. The patient's symptoms are likely related to metformin use.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. It consists of five components: cyanosis, retractions, grunting, air entry, and respiratory rate (RR). Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total possible score of 10. Here's the breakdown for the given case:

 

 

Summing up the scores:


1 (cyanosis) + 1 (retractions) + 2 (grunting) + 2 (air entry) + 0 (RR) = 6

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-1, C-3, D-4, E-5

 

The correct matching of the items is as follows:

 

  • Eonism (Transvestism): Wearing clothes of the opposite sex, often for sexual gratification or due to gender identity disorder.
  • Frotteurism: The act of rubbing one's genitals against another person, usually in a crowded place.
  • Necrophilia: Engaging in sexual activity with dead bodies.
  • Exhibitionism: The act of exposing one's genitalia to unsuspecting individuals.
  • Passive Algoglenia: Deriving sexual gratification from experiencing pain, also known as masochism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism (Transvestism) is wearing clothes of the opposite sex, Frotteurism is rubbing genitals against another person, Necrophilia is having sex with dead bodies, Exhibitionism is exposing genitalia to unsuspecting individuals, and Passive Algoglenia is gratification from experiencing pain.

choices.text: Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen
Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the likely organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most commonly affects lungs

 

The image shows encapsulated yeast cells characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungal pathogen primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia as its initial manifestation. After infecting the lungs, it can disseminate to other organs, most notably the central nervous system, where it causes meningitis. The lung involvement is typically the first and most common site of infection for Cryptococcus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yeast cells with Pseudohyphae are seen: Incorrect. Cryptococcus neoformans appears as round yeast cells with a characteristic capsule. It does not form pseudohyphae, which are more commonly associated with Candida species.

 

Option C. Humans are the only reservoir: Incorrect. The main environmental reservoirs for Cryptococcus neoformans are bird droppings (especially pigeons) and certain trees like eucalyptus. Humans are not considered reservoirs for this organism.

 

Option D. Severe infection is seen if CD4 count is below 900: Incorrect. Severe cryptococcal infections are typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly HIV patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/μL, not 900.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans most commonly affects the lungs as the primary site of infection, followed by potential dissemination to other organs, especially the central nervous system.

questions.text: A patient with O negative and husband B positive delivered a baby. Has received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks. In which of the following conditions will you give anti-D post-delivery? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Baby +ve, DCT -ve

 

In cases where an Rh-negative mother has delivered a baby, the administration of anti-D immunoglobulin post-delivery is crucial if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative.

 

  • Rh incompatibility: The Rh-negative mother may develop antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells if fetal-maternal hemorrhage occurs. To prevent this alloimmunization and protect future pregnancies, anti-D immunoglobulin is given to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that might have entered the maternal circulation during delivery.
  • Direct Coombs Test (DCT): This test checks whether antibodies are already attached to the baby's red blood cells. A negative DCT indicates that the fetal RBCs are free of maternal antibodies. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, anti-D is administered to the mother to prevent the formation of antibodies in her system.

 

The administration of anti-D within 72 hours of delivery is standard practice to ensure that any fetal red blood cells in the mother’s circulation are neutralized, thereby preventing Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baby O negative, DCT negative: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of isoimmunization

 

Option B. Baby O negative, DCT positive: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of iso immunization

 

Option C. Baby Positive, DCT positive: In this patient although the Baby is Rh positive , but DCT is positive which means Abs have already formed in the mother and hence there is no use of giving her Anti D

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative to prevent Rh sensitization and protect future pregnancies.

choices.text: Tandem mass spectrometry
Complete blood count (CBC)

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred diagnostic tool for screening metabolic diseases, particularly inborn errors of metabolism (IEM), in children. This technology allows for the simultaneous detection of multiple metabolic disorders by measuring the levels of various metabolites in a single blood sample.

 

The high sensitivity and specificity of tandem mass spectrometry make it an ideal choice for newborn screening programs. It can detect a wide range of metabolic disorders early, enabling prompt intervention that can prevent severe complications and improve long-term outcomes. The method works by ionizing chemical compounds and then analyzing the ions based on their mass-to-charge ratio, which allows for precise identification and quantification of different substances in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete blood count (CBC): CBC is a basic test that measures different components of the blood, such as red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. While it provides essential information about overall health and can help diagnose various conditions, it is not specific or sensitive enough for screening metabolic diseases.

 

Option C. Urinalysis: Urinalysis is a common test that examines the content of urine. It can help detect some metabolic disorders but is not as comprehensive or effective as tandem mass spectrometry for screening a wide range of metabolic diseases.

 

Option D. Genetic testing: Genetic testing is used to identify specific genetic mutations that may cause metabolic disorders. While it can confirm a diagnosis, it is not typically used as the primary screening tool due to its complexity and the time required for analysis. Genetic testing is more often used after an initial screening suggests the presence of a metabolic disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children due to its ability to detect multiple metabolic disorders from a single blood sample.

choices.text: Fanconi syndrome presents with RTA 2
Bicarbonaturia is a feature of RTA 2
RTA 4 is associated with hypokalemia
RTA 4 is due to aldosterone resistance

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement about Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA): (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RTA 4 is associated with hypokalemia

 

Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) refers to a group of disorders characterized by defective renal acid-base regulation, leading to a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. The main types of RTA include:

 

  • RTA Type 1 (Distal RTA): Characterized by a defect in the distal tubule's ability to secrete hydrogen ions, leading to acidosis and hypokalemia.
